A simple oil extraction game suited to the casual player, but with a weak replay loop.
_________________________________________________________
Turmoil has become my go-to game to play when something is on in the background and I need just a little more mental stimulation. The game requires no long-term planning whatsoever and the gameplay loop will really determine your mileage:
The base game campaign begins with you having no equipment, very little seed money, and overall does a good job introducing you to the 'upgrades' you can purchase in town. But here there's major flaws: The 'upgrades' don't feel like real improvements because any upgrade you purchase ($15K-$40K) merely unlocks the option to pay to upgrade that function in each mining session. For example: You pay $15K to unlock wagons which can carry more oil. But then when you go to deploy wagons, you have to pay a hefty $750 in any given session to actually enable that bonus. The same goes for tunneling speed, pipe width, silo size, and wagon speed. 
In short, every upgrade you purchase is just you unlocking the right to purchase it again every single level. This makes progression feel weak.
Secondly, the stock auction in the base game is based on the dutch auction, which is an interesting historical auction method, but it's also highly annoying when you're working with highly inconsistent AI. 
_______________
I have spent nearly all my time in the game playing the DLC "the heat is on" which completely removes the dutch auction in favor of the traditional auction style. I also like that the DLC includes the expert mode's character abilities that add some nice flavor to the gameplay. 

Overall I can't recommend this game to anyone unless it's on a good sale, and even then you must be ok with a gameplay loop that never changes. The AI you play against is fickle at best and will cease to be any challenge to you (at any difficulty) once you realize that they're not programmed to think strategically about stock accumulation or attaining upgrades.

I've only completed the beginner's campaign, but it's more than enough to recommend this game. Problem solving, multitasking, and budgeting skills used to play this game. While this may seem daunting, it has a relaxing vibe with the wonderful acoustics playing in the background. Upgrading your tools is fun and is educational about how oil and gas are mined. The competition with the other computer players is a nice motivating factor to win stock of the town to become the next mayor.

Despite the competitive environment and time-limited drilling periods, this is so relaxing and enjoyable that I'd still put it into my "cozy games" bucket.  We'll just look the other way when anyone mentions "cut-throat competition" or anything like that.  Yep.  
Really satisfying mechanics in a clean and easy interface, helped along by atmospheric sound design.  
It's good, wholesome fun.

Challenging, unique, and fun. A round takes around 15 minutes. There is a save feature in campaign mode. 

Once learned, you will find yourself trying to find and extract oil while avoiding too much production/spillage while at the same time trying to find and get it all out of the ground while adjusting transportation to obtain the best sale price. A fine balance and timing! 

Timing is everything in this great little business and exploration scenario. Strategy and economics apply as you seek deposits to exploit and out finance your opponents into submission via the stock market between rounds. Bid on land to drill and buy stock in the town. Upgrade upgrade upgrade your tools and equipment for maximum efficiency! Be careful though, if you make an error is a bit unforgiving. Some blunders can end like a rouge type adventure. Game over! But, you will start again, and do better next try. 

Understanding how gas deposits enhance pricing will be beneficial. Again, timing and preparation for the gas extracting is paramount. If done correctly, you can elevate the oil prices and who knows, maybe become world famous on the leader board and record books! 

I give this one a 9 out of 10. A real gem.

Turmoil, developed by Gamious and released in 2016, is a strategy game set in the Wild West where players can build and manage a successful oil company.

One of the most remarkable features of Turmoil is its simplicity and depth. The game has an intuitive user interface that makes it easily accessible, yet it offers a wealth of decisions and challenges that allow players to test and improve their entrepreneurial skills.

Another outstanding feature of Turmoil is its graphic design. The game has beautiful hand-drawn graphics that perfectly fit the Wild West theme. The sound effects and music also create an authentic atmosphere.

Players have the opportunity to build their own oil company, from exploring oil fields to buying land and equipment, and selling the extracted oil. They must make strategic decisions to keep their company profitable.

Turmoil's replayability is another strength. Each game is unique, as the positioning of oil fields and oil prices vary from game to game, presenting players with new challenges and decisions.

One potential drawback of Turmoil is that it may feel somewhat repetitive after a while, as it has a limited number of levels that may repeat.

Overall, Turmoil is a unique, entertaining, and challenging game suitable for strategy fans and those who want to become one. With its unique graphics, authentic atmosphere, and deep gameplay concept, Turmoil is definitely a game that everyone should try.

Turmoil scratches a specific itch for me. It's not an especially difficult game to learn to play. It has enough depth to keep me interested, but not so much that it's too complex to play after 10pm.

Player takes control of an oil company, prospecting for oil over a series of territories. They compete with opponents (human or AI) to get the best plots of land and eventually buy out the local mineral rights. On the way, they have to upgrade their equipment (making it faster and more valuable to find oil deposits, etc.). The oil-drilling sessions take about 15 minutes to play and they are fun!

The style of the game is cartoon-y and engaging, and the tutorial/progression in the game is great. 

All this said - it's not a game for everyone. I've had friends play it and basically turn in after the first oil-drilling session. I recommend giving it a play, if you don't enjoy it right away, don't bother buying it.
its fyie

Turmoil is a fun and engaging game that puts players in the shoes of an oil tycoon trying to strike it rich in a small town. The gameplay is challenging and addictive, with players having to carefully manage their resources and make strategic decisions in order to succeed. The game's unique setting and character-driven story add an extra layer of depth, making it a must-play for fans of strategy and management games. Overall, Turmoil is a great game that is well worth checking out.

Locate and pump the oil before the time is up, buy upgrades between levels, repeat.
It's fun for a few hours but the AI provides no challenge, the upgrades don't really matter after the few starters ones and the auction systems are useless (why would I compete for a plot that has maybe a little more oil, when I'm already making 3x what the AI is making no matter what?). It gets very repetitive very quickly. I don't hate it, but it's too simple/shallow for me to keep playing after a few hours. It's a very casual game with the level of depth of a flash/mobile game.
The game is super fun itself, and the dlc is even more worth it. There are lots of techniques that improved my gameplay, and it's quite relaxing

Every time I saw this game show up on my recommendations since 2016... I would feel my finger twitch, sometimes even so much I would put it in my cart, but at the last moment I would back out knowing that I have a tendency to drop strategy games like this shortly after trying it. Like a dead beat father who briefly returns home, only to be reminded that the new Call of Duty just came out and would rather do that instead.

The dead beat father returns home, a feeling of elation as he turns on his XBox 360... excited to play Chapter 4 of Fortnite. But then he realizes that he can't in fact play the newest Fortnite and resorts to watching Corn on the internet telly. But he lives deep in the projects with his acquaintance/drug dealer/lord and that he has only 1 bar on his cell phone connection through Virgin Mobile. He opens up Tik Tok on his T-Mobile side kick from 2oo8 and finds out his phone is also outdated.

No more Fortnite and no Wet *** ***** videos for him. It all seems dire, until he realizes that his kids have Fortnite and Tik Tok so he musters up courage once again that day and returns home. When he gets there, his kids have all grown up, went to college, got married and had kids of their own. It was at this point he reveled that his grandkids probably have Fortnite and TikTok. All he has to do is find them.

The Year is 1899 and this is story of Turmoil.

The game has some depth and its not too hard to figure out what you need to do. There aren't any cutscenes to bore you to death and you don't have to pay attention to a story. The townspeople are mildly amusing. I thought of Factorio when I played. (I always do). Factorio cost me $20 compared to Turmoil $10 but Factorio is a way of life, a religion and probably the supreme crafting, survival, whatever game. Its a religion and an addiction. Its not fair that this game sells for half its price, but its not bad and is probably better than 98% of the games on Steam.

Do I find myself wanting to play the game while I'm doing something else like surfing the web? Yes. I often think, "I'd like to give that another go." To me that's one of the more important qualities of a game.  Its something to go to when you're a little bored, even if you finished the campaign. The single player on the bonus island can be completed in about 20 minutes and it offers a lot of challenge and replay value and yet it won't take up your whole day like some games. The map can change with each play or not so that does keep it fresh. Juggling time limits and the need to drain oil and gas and produce a maximum profit ensures your mind will be busy with strategic thinking. I just wish I could more precisely lay pipes to use every bit of space for expanding gas. And I don't think it would hurt to include an optional pause to work on things while paused. 

I've played a little more now and one thing that keeps me coming back is that it was easy to figure out how to get started but it also has this thermal upgrade. You can surround pockets of gas with pipes to heat up the gas and expand it. In effect you are taking a small pocket of gas and turning it into a huge pocket. This can be used to drive up the price of oil at the incs  where your wagons deliver oil. It takes time though and your time is limited. You also have to be careful not to vent your gas through your drilling rigs. This will drive oil to the surface faster, but it won't increase the price of oil. At first this looks simple but there's a fine line between making 10,000 or  250,000. It can be pretty hard to do the later but often you end up with about 60,000. You know you can do better. That's how the game keeps you coming back.  Its a really nice, original game mechanic in a cheap game. Thats why I think Turmoil is exceptional. Good gameplay, plus something really clever that I've never seen before in any game.

All in all this game offers the best strategic thinking in years and it uses gameplay mechanics I've never seen before.

In short, this is a very good pick-up-and-play type of game, if you're into this type of gameplay anyway.

Its rules and logic are a bit quirky, but once you've learned them, you'll get better at it the more you play. Sounds obvious, but I'm just saying it's a little tricky at first, and the learning-curve isn't that steep or at least big.
It does need a little re-balancing in the difficulty, as "Normal" quickly becomes too easy and "Expert" (which you unlock after completing the campaign on Normal difficulty) is way more balanced and challenging. The latter can be punishing at some points, but at least it gives a challenge. - So, in my view, there really should be a new "Normal" difficulty that falls between the current "Normal" and "Expert". If not, just rework "Normal" and add an optional "Easy" or "Introductory" mode for first-time players and such, then only let "Normal" and "Expert" count for real.

Other than that, it's one of those games that are easy to get into and have the potential to become addicting for a while. It does get a little repetitive, as there's a rather tight gameplay-loop, so it's not something for hundreds of hours, perhaps not even dozens. But it's definitely a nice game to play for an hour or two every day for a while and then let go of again and come back to later.

There's something really relaxing about pretending to be an oil baron in the old west. About pulling every dirty trick in the book without running afoul of silly things like antitrust laws or ethics. About discovering oil, then ravaging the pristine western wilderness with your oil rigs and your silos and your wagons and bribing folks to sell as high as you can to the two anarchronisticly wonder gas stations on either side of your screen.

Works you brain, but doesn't tug at your emotions. It's really kind of zen to play. I've played the original SO MANY TIMES, and finally finished campaign mode of The Heat Is On. 

The Heat is On is WAY HARDER at the beginning than the original was, and I found I had to make a lot more use of the on-the-spot loans in the oilfield to be able to make any profit. Once you have all the magma tech though, the delightful science-ish ness of messing with the elements with heat is SO FUN. Make sure you watch a video of how to make the magma interact with the gas. I didn't, so the first part was super hard. But I really enjoyed it by the end. 

One complaint: I wish I could get to The Heat is ON bonus island after defeating the campaign. Or play the bonus island more than once. I want to play with those end mechanics without having to play all the way through campaign mode.

Such a good management style game. Easy to hop in and out of and has an awesome vibe from the music to the art. So far with the short time I've played, its a wonderful, fun, and reasonably priced game.

Oh Turmoil, one of the perfect games for just starting out PC players such as myself a couple of weeks before writing this. Such an incredibly enjoyable game with absolutely no obligations at any time. You can just play a simple level and never even need to start the campaign to experience what is most enjoyable about Turmoil, the oil mining sections. But if you truly want the full experience, you must play the campaign. It changes the region you mine in every now and again to keep it fresh and exciting at all times. There is an abundance of upgrades you can acquire to make your oil drilling excursions more eventful and effective. There is truly no comparison to this game, it is absolutely a one-of-a-kind experience. I only wish I could experience it all over again. The learning curve is here, and it is relatively forgiving as there are so many levels to redeem yourself if you mess up in previous levels, you can come back from a lousy start in no time which in a game like this, is vitally important. I cannot recommend it more. Thank you.

I saw Drae play it and thought it looked like a good strategy management game. It's quite addictive but after an hour or two I have to take a break. Each dig is like 20 minutes of chaos trying to keep an eye on the best prices, not overflow your oil rigs, and debate whether it's worth sending another mole or not. 

As the game goes on things get more complicated and it's not just about digging as much oil as you can. Some levels have very limited oil and the only way to make a profit is to store your oil until the very end and try and jack the price up with gas. Very intense micromanaging! I'm not that far in yet but it's very fun.

Some people may argue that Turmoil is not a deep and challenging management game. Because the game doesn't give you proper tools to enable you min/max properly, it loses a lot of depth in that department. But I think that's intentional, because that's what the developer wanted to provide. Therefore Turmoil remains a very chill and smooth kind of experience.

Although it's not the game that is going to keep you learning deep and challenging management systems for hours, Turmoil is an enjoyable, small management game which is definitely worth the price.

Fun and simple game, it offers some micromanagement skills but is very simple to learn. Very addictive and has high replay capability in my opinion. Solid Game!
I've been playing all different types of games for ages (since the early days of video games), and this is surprisingly great. The graphics are simple, the rules/gameplay are not too involved, yet it manages to grab my attention and make me want to keep playing for long periods of time. 
Each level is pretty short (maybe a 15 minute investment) with good upgrade options between levels. And as you go through the campaign you get new mechanics and upgrades introduced at a reasonable pace to keep it feeling a bit fresh. 

It's not a super lengthy game, but I've come back to it after a long hiatus and am really enjoying it once again. I strongly recommend it.

Pretty fun little game to kill some time and distract you for a bit.  Charming art direction and solid game mechanics, though not too challenging once you figure things out (suppose that can be good or bad).  

My only real complaint is that some of the mechanics later in the game that you can utilize seem difficult enough to take advantage of that it seems to make sense to just not use them.  You get these natural-gas pockets later in the game that you can use to make more money, but I found more often than not, it was easier just to ignore them and keep going about your businesses as if they weren't there.  Mostly because it would take more time to make them work properly than you had available for each dig.  It would be nice if it was better implemented, because it would add little bit more complexity if this and some of the other mechanics worked better.

So give this game a few hours and as simple as the graphics are, the gameplay is awesome.  It is challenging as well as fun.  Did almost 5 hours all at once.  The scanner is the best way to find your oil fast and then if you are low of funds I use the mole.  Alot of the upgrades are not worth it, but you won't learn that until you try them.  But that is part of the fun of the game.  Really enjoy clearing out everything each time, and ending the round right before the time is up is a great way to make an extra $1000.  This is a non-violent game which my son will be reviewing on his radio show next week.  (The Tiberius Show)  This is safe for kids to play and a great way to get them to compete to see who can get farther faster.  Great job DEV team.

I reinstall this game every couple of months to play a campaign and was in the middle of doing so when the dev's released a patch on Oct. 12, 2021 which just ruined the entire game.
When this update is installed automatically any campaign you currently have going is incompatible with the new update so you need to start over or know to have auto updates turned off but I decided to start over and give the (now automatically installed update) a try, boy was that a huge mistake.
After starting a new campaign and playing about a half dozen turns I really screwed up a level really bad so I decided to quit halfway through the year and restart, guess what, I can't because the game freaking saves your game in the middle of the year so a single mistake can completely screw you over to the point where recovery may not be possible.
Now sure there is a way to undo the update to go back to the old version of the game but I never thought to write it down and for some reason it is not noted anywhere in game like on the title screen where you know it would be very handy to have so people like me could use the version of the game we (used to) enjoy playing.
Why would you not just make it so you can swap between classic and new game modes is beyond me.

A simple indie game revolving around mining oil and making money. It has a simple style, straight forward and simple mechanics with satisfying visual feedback. There isn't much to say on the game overall. If you're interested in the game i'd recommend checking out a short spurt of gameplay on youtube. If it looks like it might interest you, then it probably will. It is a short game, taking me around 4 to 5 hours to beat its campaign, however i would recommend you play this game in short bursts, otherwise it will feel repetitive with you doing the same loop of mining and buying land over and over until you're finished. It's a simple but satisfying game and it usually goes for pretty cheap. Would Recommend.

Amazing little game for anyone who likes building/resource casual games. This isn't so casual when you hit expert mode, holy moly. Simple for pugs, very challenging to master (but you don't have to!), great replayability in all cases and addictive game play with RNG that is not at the core of the game mechanics (the RNG determines amount and placement of resources on each level but there are ways to mitigate that through tech/exploration - it's a good application of RNG that avoids it getting anywhere close to rogues while still keeping things unpredictable and spicy). 

TL;DR: amazing game at a great price, plus the devs are reworking it currently so a new iteration en-route. Cannot recommend highly enough for an addictive little casual pug game with actual SPINE and challenge too. Impressed.

Edit: if only the weekly challenge could be made daily... hint hint devs !!!!

A management game cheerfully celebrating the extraction of fossil fuels for the enrichment of billionaires, Turmoil is a lightweight good time with the vague air of a superior noughties Flash game. Drill for oil, sell it, use the profits to buy upgrades between levels to expedite the further drilling of oil. Repeat until the Amazon has burned down and the Artic is boiling. A little additional complexity is introduced about midway through the campaign by ‚Äì and you might want to sit down for this ‚Äì natural gas. Otherwise that‚Äôs it.

Is Turmoil going to win retroactive innovator of the year award for 2016? No. But it deliver interesting variations on its core loop? Also no. What Turmoil does is provide a kind of glassy-eyed charm with a simple and compelling enough premise to while away a few pleasant hours. If you‚Äôve had a busy day at work and just want to click on numbers to make them get bigger, you could do a lot worse.
a fun game to play when you have time

Fun little game, exactly what I was looking for.
I needed something simple to play as I listen to podcasts and was a bit bored with solitaire.

The game is easy to get into. Nicely guides you into playing it adding new things as you go.
In the end it does offer a challenge but nothing overwhelming (although I have only just played through the first part of the campaign. Not sure how hard it gets after that).

What you do in the game is you put up an oil pump, drill a pipe down and hope you'll hit oil. 
There are some ways to enhance your chances of finding the oil, like a mole that digs down and reveals random spots.
Then, when you have the pipe in an oil pocket, oil starts pouring out and you can sell it. The price of the oil changes, so you have to manage which two companies to sell it to or you can also storage it.
In the campaign mode between digs you go back to town where you can buy upgrades and see if you sold more oil than 3 competing AI characters.

Turmoil feels like a flash game, but it's wrapped up in pretty western Americana paper and topped off with a bow of long-term strategy. True to the trailer, it IS a very relaxing experience. 

In Turmoil, you are a would-be oil baron somewhere in midwestish America. Each turn you choose a site to drill for oil and dig up as much as you can before time runs out, selling to the highest bidder (either RED or BLU). The more you sell, the more persistent upgrades you can buy to make it easier in the next turn. 

It's really fun and it's simple. Once you get the hang of it, I imagine you'll have no problem clearing levels to 100% drained every time. Unfortunately, that's where Turmoil kind of breaks down. It's too easy; the AI opponents hardly earn anything and there aren't enough features to play long term. It feels like it needed more options or hazards while staying in theme. 

While Turmoil is fun and it has great theming and music, it still plays like a flash game and, for that reason, I think it's best to wait until this one is on sale.

I'm not even 3 hours in and the game already seems repetitive. I will probably play it some more, but I am surprised by the Very Positive overall reviews. It does have a charm to it, both the graphics and characters, so maybe that's part of it. It's also possible people like it as a low commitment game for relaxing. It just isn't my thing personally. I'll elaborate.

There just isn't a ton to this game from what I can tell. It's an inexpensive indie game so this isn't unexpected, but I don't see anything that makes it engaging outside of the classic feedback loop of gathering a resource (in this case money) so that you can unlock upgrades that help you gather said resource faster/more efficiently. That formula can work well in my experience if the game is more engaging in other ways such as introducing new mechanics more frequently, having some kind of story to progress, having mini games, etc.

First, I don't even get the land bidding piece, it feels pointless. As far as I can tell there is no indication as to how good a particular plot of land is going to be so you are just blindly bidding. Since you are playing against AI and you always get to go first, the result is that you click a random plot of land and they either outbid you or pick a different plot. If they outbid you on the plot you picked you can bid even higher or simply pick a different plot. Since you have no way of knowing if the plot is even good and aren't playing against real people that you might have motives against, there is no incentive to outbid the AI ever, so you just end up picking a new plot every time to keep the cost at the minimum 2k. So the land bidding comes down to a mandatory 2k payment to get into the next instance, like throwing your ante in during a poker game. If I am missing something, joke's on me I guess.

So far it looks like the upgrades are mostly around the units/mechanics you start off with. You have guys that find oil, so here's an upgrade to have them do it faster, and another that allows them to find it deeper. You have wagons that cart the oil around, so here's an upgrade to give them more capacity. Here's an upgrade to make your oil rig use larger pipes so you can drain oil at a faster pace, and here's another to make it so you can branch multiple pipes off one joint to make pipe pathing more convenient, etc.

At one point you unlock a saloon where you can find the various shop keepers at random and they offer you seemingly randomized deals that are related to what they do or vend. For instance, you might be able to invest money into one of the oil purchasing companies to ensure their price doesn't drop below a certain amount for the next map, or you might be able to pay the warden guy to look the other way if you spill oil rather than fining you, or you might be able to pay the banker to lower the interest rate on loans, etc. This does add a bit of additional strategy to the game I suppose because it's a matter of deciding whether the cost is worth the return, but it's still just a way of modifying the cost of available services to keep spinning the feedback loop faster/slower.

My main problem with all this is that the gameplay feels like it boils down to just revising your strategy with the things you already have at each upgrade juncture until you find the most efficient way to use it (I can use 2 oil rigs now instead of 3 with the same number of horses because the rigs are grabbing oil faster). It's just constant min-maxing with the payoff being having to min-max again because the speed/capacity/cost of a particular thing changed when you spent your resource you took all that time gathering efficiently. Maybe I paid one of the oil companies to keep its price up, so maybe I made a bit more money this go around because I always had a decent price to sell at, but it doesn't really change the way I am doing things, it's just more or less money earned in an allocated amount of time. It is infrequent that you get something new and get to see if it makes sense to include it in your process.

Based on the upgrades I can actually see at this time, I would imagine end-game is something along the lines of:

*Use the scanner to find all of the oil on your map instantly, bypassing the need to use the guys to find it (I assume that's what the scanner does).
*Set up rigs and pipes to grab all the oil as quickly as possible since you are fully upgraded.
*Sell or store the oil to sell at a good price, but as fast as possible until the oil on the map is gone.
*End the map early so that you get part of your land lease cost back, maximizing profits.
*Rinse, repeat to make this process as efficient as possible to end the map as early as possible each time while still maximizing earnings from selling oil to get the most overall profit possible per map.

To conclude, in my opinion the grind to get the upgrades is boring, and being fully upgraded also sounds boring.

If you are looking for a game to kill time relatively mindlessly, this one isn't bad, but I am happy I got it for $2 - I don't think it's a $10 game as it essentially feels like a mobile game or an old flash/browser game. For me, I could kill time just as effortlessly with countless free mobile games from the comfort of my couch or the lounger in my sunroom and it would be more relaxing due to the real world setting.

If you did want to play a more relaxing game with similar progression in terms of upgrades but more interesting gameplay, I might suggest Factory Idle which is a free browser game. It requires you to upgrade intelligently according to your current bottlenecks and place all of your components in a deliberate way to maximize the space you have to work with in a grid system. I suppose it lacks the charm of this game, but personally that wears off rather quickly anyway.

I wouldn't recommend this game if it was free. It's basically a crappy flash game. The core loop is just: Place down an oil rig. Dig downwards. Wait for oil to be extracted. Next level. Again, and again, and again, with no variation. It looked like an interesting strategy/management hybrid, but the "company management" is "buy a mostly useless upgrade that will probably hurt you more than it will help". The gameplay just. never. changes. The upgrades just mean you get oil faster, but you can get all the oil in the allotted amount of time anyway. So they're practically a waste of money. But, again, the gameplay never changes. You might think "well surely those upgrades will spice it up a little!" no. They add no depth, no complexity. Just faster oil, or whatever. After you play the first level, you've played the whole game! It's about 5 minutes worth of entertainment, tops. Did I mention the gameplay never changes? I mean it. I'm repeating myself, because that's how I felt playing this game. Every level is indistinguishable. Every goal is the same. It's like star craft but you only get drones, your opponent only gets drones, and instead of fighting you both just gather minerals for 20 minutes until the game says "alright let's see who got the most minerals!"

How do you expect me to purchase a $40,000-$60,000 upgrade when the other NPCs are disposing massive amounts of their capital into town shares? It feels like I have to avoid every high-tier upgrade in order to compete. Right now, in order to win the campaign, I have to play the entire game barely purchasing upgrades. 

Due to the fact that you cannot currently utilise the upgrades, the game becomes extremely repetitive and aggravating. If the game was re-worked so that other NPC's also purchased a realistic amount of upgrades to remain profitable in the end game, or decrease the cost of upgrades all around, this game would be amazing.

You may feel like a terrible person as you start sucking the oil from the earth, but my god is it a fun game lol.
Steam shows 6.4 hours logged by the time I beat the campaign, and there's an "expert mode" that unlocks, so I'm sure you can get at least 15-20 hours out of this. Great indie game - support the crew who made this and buy it :-)

A perfectly cromulent $10 light puzzle game, if a bit repetitive. There's some strategy/simulation play but it's mostly managing money between stages. The per stage money and resource management is very tight, it's a good engaging set of problems each time. Sometimes the oil is kind, sometimes it is behind rocks. The dowser whistles and he points, mocking you. He knows you keep putting off the drill upgrade because you're buying land shares too aggressively. Each time you tell yourself "that's the last $500 crooked pipeline I make to get a pocket behind rock, this time I'll be smart." But then you hire the next pair of dowsers, resenting them instead of yourself. It's the next level. You barge into the bar angrily, demanding to see Anthony. He's not in. The vein at the mine has run dry and times are tough, he has to go further out each time. You don't care. You need to know what land to buy. You're going to have to take awful risks this time. You drink to numb the pain and see if a few guys the mechanic knows are available for union busting. It wasn't supposed to be this hard, this messy. You're afraid to sleep because last time you did you woke up talking to the mole you appointed as the dig site foreman. He can recognize diamonds and natural gas in the land and report it back to humans, he tells you.

Anyway. It's a pretty simple and light-hearted aesthetic, the meat is in optimizing your gameplay in each stage. You start off with little risk vs reward(pipe length vs overshooting the oil pocket vs costs of multiple connected lengths) and grow from there(storing oil, when to sell, how many horses and when, avoiding spills) until you're trying to set up a labyrinthian mass of pipes to heat gas pockets, stockpile oil and unleash a 10,000 Psi Combo. Managing money in town is another tight-fisted mess of risk vs reward, the constant demand for new tech eclipsing any comfort you might feel at having finally gotten out of the red. Your peers are ruthless, black chasms where their hearts should be. There isn't much of a sim aspect here really but managing your money is a pretty concrete problem.

It's a cruel profession, a harsh master that cripples and kills men indiscriminately. It's about worth the $10 for a one and done, well worth more than that if you feel the bite and keep going. Replays to learn the best loadouts, weekly challenges, expert mode. You could easily break 10 hours trying to 100% this one. It'll only cost you your soul.

A charming light strategy game about scarcity management. Oil is limited, time is limited, money is especially limited, and you're trying to juggle all these balls at once. 

While this would be a perfect strategy game to get a preteen to understand what opportunity cost is about, it's still very entertaining for an adult, and since rounds last about 5-10 minutes, it can be played in small doses. 

I suppose graphics options aren't great, and the DLC is hit and miss, but otherwise, give this a try.

Turmoil is a simple, charming simulation game that can make for some casual fun

Pro's
- Relaxing, quirky western music.
- Suitably cartoon-ish visuals and environments.
- Enjoyable game-play loop of mining oil.
- Very satisfying to earn lots of money on a single plot of land.
- Some nice additional mechanics like durable rocks and gas pockets vary the game a little.
- Fun characters.


Neutral
- Doesn't have a story, other than buying up share to become the next mayor.
- Some people might feel the game gets too repetitive by the end of a 9 hour play-through, whilst other will enjoy it.


Con's
- Normal mode is insanely easy once you get the hang of the game (I managed to buy over 85% of the town shares without trying very hard, when only 51% is needed to "win" the game). Conversely, the hard mode is a bit too difficult, with the AI earning ridiculous sums of money from terrible plots of land.
- Some of the equipment upgrades are either useless or not worth the cost (and yes I am talking about the damn moles).
- The last few plots of each of the four biomes are usually not fun to mine as they are very poor quality and pay barely any money.


Overall, Turmoil is a nice, likeable simulation game that provides a chill experience.

I don't get to play it as much as I would like, but I know that it is always going to be one of those games that I can pick up and play without having to worry about anything going wrong. I am happy to recommend this game to anyone that would like a small challenge for at least your first round. It is not a hard game and the things that you have to manage can seem like it is to much, but it only takes a couple of times to get it all worked out and working for you.

Before that it was fun to play, but this support is really bad.

This game is perfect. 

It feels so polished and so structured and so fair and perfect and fun. At no point have I felt mad or frustrated or like the game was not correctly reflecting my intent of what I was trying to do. When I win, I know why I won, and when I lose, I know why I lost, and at every moment I feel like the game is doing exactly what I want it to be doing. At no moment do I feel like a situation is out of my control or unfair, and when things go badly I think to myself "ok so that was a bad idea, I can learn from this". 

The timing is perfect! It's great to jump in and kill 3 minutes during a brief downtime, it's great to kill 5 hours when I've got nothing to do. I can play this game exactly how and when I want. 

I have not encountered a single bug. There's a perfect amount of world building and character development through a very minimal amount of reading.

 I am incredibly critical of games, have been playing video games since the 80s, and this is a rare gem. It would be a deal at twice the price, and I haven't been this happy with a purchase since I bought an Earthbound cartridge for my SNES in 1994.

This game right here is a perfect example of how game design should be done. I have no further suggestions.

It reminds me of M.U.L.E.  Simple initially, but actually longer term decision making follows the rules of economics, finance, geology, and market forces.  I am not one to review products, and this is a fun, good game, not absolutely the best ever.  Why am I reviewing this?  Because I actually invest in oil companies for a living.  And believe me, as simplistic as the basic premise is, and despite the cartoon graphics, this is a realistic model of how oil companies actually succeed and fail.  From the "buy land near where oil was found", to "invest in transportation infrastructure early, but only up to the point of diminishing returns", this is a surprisingly good way to teach folks who are not familiar with the industry the basics behind how it works.  

I'm actually considering having my junior staff play this game for a 10 hours as part of their industry training.  No crazier than having combat troops or pilots play Counter Strike or Flight Simulator.

Picky gamer here but full disclosure: I have a soft spot for minimalist design, media that has roots in American "Western" era and I like money management.

Now having said that, I would say that this game is a decent casual game to pickup and play in short bursts. The game itself is fairly easy and most of the in-game upgrades are not really needed once you get the hang of production so in one way this creates a no stress game. In another way, this game is fairly shallow and a bit boring. Thankfully, the game does offer a feature to speed up the game. 

Overall I think what made this game fun for me is very subjective and I understand why many people would not like it. I would only really recommend this game to people that are looking for a simple money management game that is quickly finished and does not offer too much in the way of gameplay variety. 

The bad parts of this game that I don't think anyone could argue with are as follows: the AI is dumb and doesn't pose much of a challenge,  the game is very repetitive with very little variety, the game is short and many of the in-game upgrades are not needed. On the hardest difficulty setting the game goes from too easy to ball-crushingly difficult as the AI accumulates huge sums of money and is always able to outbid you.

Despite these short comings, I found this game worth my time and money. The game isn't amazing but if you have an interest in money/resource management games and like the "Western" look I would recommend this game.

I saw, I oil, I oil

It's relaxing and hectical at once. The game offers a noticable learning curve where you go from poking in the earth to becoming a oil prince(ss). I had it on my wishlist for a while untill I saw it on a sale. The moment it came on sale I bought it and sat 4 hours straight learning the secret of oil. I have no regrets.

So what do you actually do in Turmoil?

The plot of the game is to compete against others in a oil rush. There's 4 maps you'll be competing in, where each map increases the difficulty with new "resources" & "blockages". To keep up with the competition you'll have to spend your profits wisely on upgrades in your town.

There's a big factor of decision making in the game. From what to buy, when to buy to where you wish to begin and where potential secrets are in your map. Each map makes you improve your strategy due to its difficulty which is a great feature as you feel you're continuously improving and theres no rinse & repeat feeling.

With that there's also a 2nd mode that unlocks new features and difficulty. Giving more value to your dollars and total playtime.

Pros & Cons

Due to the games learning curve you'll get a consistent feel of mastery. The competition part of the game is a interesting touch to the game and definitely motivates you to perform.

A downside is that the game is perhaps a little rushed. I didn't feel like I had the time to buy more features and ended up rushing my experience

the ng+ feature adds more life to the game. definitely worth a look at once you get there.

Conclusion. Should you buy Turmoil?

The first completion of the game lasts you anywhere from 5 to 6 hours, which almost hits you the "1 dollar an hour". However, if you wish to try out the ng+ mode you'll definitely get value for your dollar.

I personally sat 4 hours straight because I loved it so much. Its different to what I usually play and the change was appreciated.

At first, it's a rather simplistic game, but the more that you play and progress throughout the campaign, the deeper the game play systems, and overall mechanics of the game get.

What's interesting is that it never gets too complicated, is a difficult game to learn in the sense that it's difficult to develop strategies initially.

Mainly because the game locks you out of a lot of mechanics at the beginning of the campaign that it really shouldn't lock you out of.

Like the ability to speed up the game, this is a game that's in grave need of systems, that have become staples of the genre.

Speed controls, the ability to resell buildings, and/or units that you don't need.

Generally tho, if you stick with the game for a while, and get past the initial headache, you'll find a game that has a very pleasant look, and an addictive game play curve.

The game has a fairly long campaign, a quick mode of play, and I believe even multiplayer.

I recommend it, it's a great game.

This game has numerous unpleasant quirky mechanics that seem like bugs. Some are explained in-game, for a fee.

For example, sometimes a douser will identify an oil reservoir that you can't see because it is lower than the bottom of the screen. You can't scroll down to access this reservoir. For $25, the mayor will sell you a tip suggesting that you wait until later in the year to use that reservoir, because the screen automatically scrolls down slowly over the course of the year. This fact is not obvious until you see the paid tip. I can't think of any logical reason for this scrolling behavior.

Some features, like being able to repay a loan, are simply missing. This seems to be developer laziness, rather than some inexplicable balancing choice.

This game misses clicks. I find that sometimes I click on something three or four times without it registering. As a workaround, I have to hold down the left mouse button for about a quarter of a second. This presumably happens because the game uses polling for the mouse buttons instead of interrupts, as it should. Reconfiguring the frame rate from 30fps to 60fps seems to help. I can't understand why any game would limit itself to 30fps, or why anyone would do input polling in the same thread that renders the graphics.

It's a very simple but very fun game where you dig for oil in a Wild West setting. 

To achieve that, you first use dousers to tell if there's oil, dig an oil rig, draw the pipes to the deposits and hire wagons to sell the oil. On each level you have a time limit and compete vs other oil tycoons.
Of course, the point is to turn a profit, and the oil prices fluctuate heavily during levels. You can choose when and how much you sell, or if you store it for when the prices rise.

In between levels you bid for plots of land against your competitors, and have a chance to improve your technology to retrieve oil faster, buy gizmos that boost your dousing/exploring ability or take a loan if you're in a tight spot.

It's an extremely simple game in terms of what you can actually do, but the gameplay can get frantic real fast.
The graphics are charming and the music, relaxing.
Very recommended for management game enthusiasts.

Turmoil is a decent simulation game, and is fine for what it is. It is a bit lacking in depth, and you can see all the gameplay it has to offer in a couple of hours. It'll take another few hours to complete it.

The good:
- good tutorial, introducing you to the mechanics, with a forgiving learning curve
- decent graphics and audio
- no bugs that I encountered
- there is an expert mode if you want more of a challenge

The not so good
- the gameplay is simple and not very challenging
- the limitation of only starting each level with a small amount of money no matter how much you actually had in the bank made each level start off slowly, and added tedium to an already repetitive game

This is a good, casual simulation game. At full price, it is cheaper than what it costs to go the movie theatre where I live, and I got over six hours of entertainment (without even playing expert mode). Recommended for people looking for casual, sim / resource management games.

In short, it was repetitive and uninteresting.  I was hoping for something with more of an economic focus, but it was a lot of playing a "level" that felt a lot like the one I just played.  I could have lived with that, as it was fairly relaxing while playing, but a look at the achievements made it clear that I was never going to 100% this game, because there were achievements that hinged heavily on RNG.  In a simulation/economic game, what sense does that make?

On the positive side of things, I really liked the presentation of the game.  As such, it was quite a disappointment after a few hours of playing and it became clear I wasn't going to play this one to finish.

There's really not much going on here.  Find a place to put a rig, drop a line, wait and try to time the market within a very short window.

And in the end, you win the game not by being good at drilling, but by winning enough auctions???  

It's part management, part economy, part strategy and part frantically clicking around, but not enough of any of these elements to solidly land in any of those camps.  It's like taking a bath in lukewarm water.  Wholly unsatisfying in every respect.

It left me frustrated rather than entertained most of the time.

[h1] I saw, I oil, I oil [/h1]

It's relaxing and hectical at once. The game offers a noticable learning curve where you go from poking in the earth to becoming a oil prince(ss). I had it on my wishlist for a while untill I saw it on a sale. The moment it came on sale I bought it and sat 6 hours straight learning the secret of oil. I have no regrets.

[h1] So what do you actually do in Turmoil? [/h1]

The plot of the game is to compete against others in a oil rush. There's 4 maps you'll be competing in, where each map increases the difficulty with new "resources" & "blockages". To keep up with the competition you'll have to spend your profits wisely on upgrades in your town. 

There's a big factor of decision making in the game. From what to buy, when to buy to where you wish to begin and where potential secrets are in your map. Each map makes you improve your strategy due to its difficulty which is a great feature as you feel you're continuously improving and theres no rinse & repeat feeling. 

With that there's also a 2nd mode that unlocks new features and difficulty. Giving more value to your dollars and total playtime.

[h1] Pros & Cons [/h1]

[list]
    [*] Due to the games learning curve you'll get a consistent feel of mastery. The competition part of the game is a interesting touch to the game and definitely motivates you to perform.

    [*] A downside is that the game is perhaps a little rushed. I didn't feel like I had the time to buy more features and ended up rushing my experience

    [*] the ng+ feature adds more life to the game. definitely worth a look at once you get there.
[/list]

[h1] Conclusion. Should you buy Turmoil? [/h1]

The first completion of the game lasts you anywhere from 5 to 6 hours, which almost hits you the "1 dollar an hour". However, if you wish to try out the ng+ mode you'll definitely get value for your dollar.

I personally sat 6 hours straight because I loved it so much. Its different to what I usually play and the change was appreciated.

Thanks for reading my review of Turmoil.

A fun little strategy game where you roleplay as an oil baron without all the psychopathy. 

Each round is satisfying and engaging as you strive to get as much oil out of the ground as possible and sell it at the highest price.  In between rounds, you'll use your profits to buy upgrades for your oil extraction and storage tools and eventually shares.  Shares represent the win condition for the campaign as you seek to acquire a majority stake in the town to become mayor.   Strategy and challenge ramp up over the course of a campaign as you unlock new upgrades and oil becomes more difficult to extract.  Maximizing your profits and then spending them wisely will be the keys to success.  I found this dynamic to be fun and rewarding. 

Sound effects, music and art all accompany the gameplay nicely, definitely capturing a mood of the Old West about to turn New West.  UI works nicely and I did not encounter any bugs. 

The expansion for this game hones the gameplay and balance that saw some mechanics be a little underwhelming in the original campaign.  Definitely worth picking up if you enjoy the base game.  

Overall, I'd give this game a B, a solid game worth your time if it sounds interesting.

I feel like this game is stuck in a weird place where it's too deep for a phone game, but not complicated enough for a computer game.  You build wells and then build pipes to find oil in a way that reminds me of that line from There Will Be Blood... "I drink your milkshake."  Ultimately, though, this game gives you a lot to do with very little reason to do it.  There's technologies, multiple places to sell your supplies, all kinds of stuff... but whether or not you out-drill the computer players will ultimately come down to dumb luck.   If I did well in a scenario it's because I guessed that the oil was to the right.  If I did poorly it's because I guessed incorrectly that it was to the left, and there were no real tools available to me to inform that decision.  Should I deliver my oil to the Right depot or the Left depot?  Depends on which is paying more.  No brainer, no strategy, no thought process involved.  Maybe some of this improves as you develop technologies down the road but I couldn't stay engaged long enough to find out, the choices I was making were either completely obvious or total shot-in-the-dark random and I just couldn't stay interested.

A great time-killer that can land you in turmoil. Four characters to choose from, each with distinct personalities. [b] Just a 2D oil tycoon manager [/b]

Do you want to know how people earn billions of dollars sucking the Earth dry of oil? This game won't explain that to you but at least you will stick some pipes into the ground and begin pumping that liquid gold.

The gameplay is pretty simple and for casual gaming you don't even need to use all the features and perks (in fact, it seems that quite a bunch of them are useless). During the main campaign even that small variety of levels is not that challenging and the strategy remains the same all the time, which makes it boring really fast.

I have enjoyed 'Turmoil' for being exactly what it is supposed to be: a 2D oil tycoon manager. Nothing more to it, several hours of casual digging and you will get over it.

Have fun while it lasts.

So I started the oil business. Being daring, I am quick to make profit, above my peers; in my first run. Then, I started betting way too much, taking loan too big. In the end my business got bankrupt. It was calculated, but as you know, you'll never know exactly how much profit you are going to make in the next year.

Having learnt that being too bold can be fatal, I started being more careful in my second run. Im still in the third stage, but I can say I am improved more; balancing profit with stock share while keeping enough money for the next campaign.

Im glad this is a simulation lol. It is quite realistic. I can see from this game why business rivalries can be so fatal in real life. I can see better on how business works too in real life. Though that mechanics didn't really exist here; it seems all play quite fair.

Tldr; good game, but can be quite repetitive after a while.

Seeing this game 80% off and knowing nothing about it I thought, "eh, worst case I waste a couple of bucks". Best case scenario was that I find a real gem of a game. Really fun. I've seen negative comments about the gameplay being repetitive but actually I thought the game mechanics where really engaging. However, I have to admit that if I had payed full price I would have had higher expectations of the game. The graphics are simple and charming, as too is the music, but at $15 (Aussie dollar), I would probably have expected a bit more in terms of the presentation. Otherwise, it is a super enjoyable and rewarding game, and I will likely invest in the DLC with or without a sale.

When you think of oil production in the US, Texas and Oklahoma probably spring to mind. Pennsylvania probably doesn't. But In 1859 Edwin Drake drilled the first oil well in the US near Titusville PA. Okay  not exactly, there were other wells producing oil before that, but he was the first one who was actually LOOKING for oil. Black Gold. Texas Tea. People serving possums in Hollywood . . . Sorry, bit o' nostalgia there. Anyway, with Turmoil, you too can be a greedy exploiter of Mother Earth's natural resources, without feeling the slightest bit of guilt. Not that J.P. Morgan probably ever felt guilty about anything anyway . . . You can feel the thrill as the precious black liquid gurgles up the pipes and into your waiting wagons. Watch your profits rise (or fall, but let's not dwell on that). And all without suffering the awful H__l that is Texas and Oklahoma at-well at pretty much any time of the year. My brother worked in the oil fields in Oklahoma and I spent xmas with him one year. I have to admit that, after I'd been there less than a day, my thought was: "Oh my God, I can't believe that, after shoving the poor Cherokee onto this god-forsaken piece of real estate, fifty years later they were lining up to take it away from them. And that was BEFORE they discovered oil there . . ." No, I'll happily watch my little wells burping oil in 'Turmoil ' instead. At least my exposed flesh won't freeze within one minute.
My abiding memory of Turmoil is watching a YouTuber get angry about the 'Stupid Dancing Horses' and thinking 'I can do better'. So I did. ;) Lots of fun.

I bought the game on sale for 2‚Ç¨ (~2.20$). I wasn't expecting much but I was looking for a small way to spend some time. I actually didn't believe what a great game I got there for 2‚Ç¨.

It is bug-free, has a great graphics-style and is overall nice to look at. The game has many features and brakes down complex economical principles (Storage-Cost-Calculations, investments in infrastructure, interest rates vs. ROI, basic stock trading) into an understandable, easily playable, fun experience.

If you're into strategy games, Management-Simulations or basically into economics / finance, this is the game to buy.

Another great feature: The developing company doesn't seem to be after the money only. They released the game when it was playable and bug-free, and kept developing.
I reaaaaally hope that they keep producing new features.

Only problem: The game rounds are too short sometimes as you could use more advanced strategies if you had more time. Also the maps can be a little small.
Another con: There is no Multiplayer.
Apart from this, perfect!

I rate this 9/10.

Good game of digging for riches.. I really enjoy coming back to this game for a few games at a time in a long campaign. I enjoy games of digging for hidden resources, selling to volatile market economies, building upgrades with profits, and competing with AI competitors. I have a lot of fun trying to maximize every single dollar of profit.

The first half of the campaign has a similar level-townupgrade cycle, but then the game goes into natural gas and heating, where it loses points with me. Those game mechanisms are not well explained, unlike the excellent initial tutorial, and it is tricky to use them for profit. Struggling to get these mechanism working on each level adds a lot of stress to an otherwise relaxing game.

One biiiiig problem with the linux version is that the Daily Challenge does not work at all and sometimes crashes the game.

The developer's note in comments references a different issue, which I fixed with the GM2 engine workaround, by changing the launch parameters to: R600_DEBUG="vs,ps" %command%

Anyway, this game is built on Game Maker 2, and it uses the mouse with keyboard shortcuts. The game uses 135 MBs of diskspace, and the very classy guitar soundtrack is located on the disk, in vorbis encoded format. I played this game on an ubuntu linux 18.10 & 19.10 desktop, with radeon mesa drivers, including an old 900MHz CPU

Will recommend for 2‚Ç¨

[u][b]What I Loved:[/b][/u]
[list]
    [*]I enjoyed the relaxing atmosphere, the music sets the tone and the art makes you feel like you're in the 19'th century.
    [*]How it initially seemed like you were progressing gameplay wise after each dig.
[/list]

[u][b]What I Accepted:[/b][/u]
[list]
    [*]Upgrades are expensive, likely to last the entire campaign.
    [*]Upgrades aren't friendly, take the wrong one and you're screwed until the next 3-4 digs.
    [*]None of the characters get much of any development, they're there give reasons behind mechanics.
[/list]

[u][b]What I Despised:[/b][/u]
[list]
    [*]The gameplay [i]very[/i] quickly became repetitive.
    [*]The relaxing atmosphere is destroyed by how short each dig level is.
    [*]A relaxing atmosphere is complemented with a myriad of small tasks and unique obstacles in each dig level, otherwise it increases the intensity of one‚Äôs boredom.
    [*]The crux of the problem is how shallow the game actually is. There‚Äôs barely any content, and the upgrades are high in price to stretch the game length rather than to keep it interesting.
    [*]The only way to enjoy this game is to play one dig level each irl day in order to enter the perfect mental state for sleep, which isn‚Äôt the kind of game I expected from the videos.
    [*]It takes too long to afford all of the upgrades and as a result, it feels like you‚Äôre not progressing at a comfortable speed. The cheapest upgrade takes three dig levels to even approach the amount of money necessary to safely buy, and most of the upgrades are barely unique or interesting. Notice that this game has [i]four[/i] main areas‚Äîthe longer to bore you with!
[/list]

[h1]Conclusion & Rating[/h1]

I wish I could say "yes" and recommend.  But, there is an issue that the developers acknowledge was an issue years ago, but no change has yet been made to fix it.

When you want to connect natural gas to a left or right company, you can't build from the company.  Worse part is, every youtube video out there they do this.  But, in the reality of the game, and the talk on the help information online, you still can't do that.  Instead you need to connect it from your existing pipes... all the while those pipes are connected to oil pockets and this just wont work.  I even had an abandond tower and pipe system set.... and the price didn't go anywhere for that company.

It has been years since this was brought up on youtube, here in steam, and other locations where players are giving suggestions and even the Dev's are posting.  Yet, no change.  My last save is  now stuck with a very expensive gas sell upgrade and no way to use it.  

Fix this issue, make it work like  it does on your own companies youtube video, and I'll give it a "Yes".

In summary, you buy some land and attempt to suck out as much oil as possible within a time limit.  Your profits depend on an ever fluctuating sale price that jumps wildly throughout the timed drilling session.  The game attempts to throw in a few mechanics that are meant to make it more interesting, like running gas lines to an oil company in order to boost the oil price...  This doesn't make any sense to me, but heck its just a game.  

The whole thing plays out in the form of a competition between you and a handful of AI opponents.   There is no real plot, heck this is basically a glorified minigame.

Unfortunately once you get past the first chapter of the game you are hit with a new game mechanic that is just plain annoying: "running for mayor" by means of buying magical "mayor stock" in a competitive auction format.  Sorry devs but you really lost me here.  I can ignore the absurdity of buying stocks to become a mayor- it is just a goofy game- but what I cannot ignore is the fact that the game basically forces you to blow the majority of your earnings on acquiring a "stock" rather than buying upgrades that would actually make the game more enjoyable.  If you choose not to go along with this and actually spend your money on upgrades it will simply mean a game over screen sooner, rendering your upgrades useless.

Seriously, is there some sort of natural progression from oil prospector to government office that I am unaware of?  This whole thing seems to be pulled out of left field.  

Imagine that half way through witcher 3 you were suddenly informed that you needed to put the majority of your experience/ability points into a new special category labeled "geologist."  There is no way to beat the game without being fully specced as a geologist.  You will never be able to use any of the abilities or perks in this skill tree, but without it Siri and Yenifer will simply drop dead towards the end of the game due to some unexpected geological accident that doesn't quite fit into the story- an event that can only be thwarted by a geologist witcher.   

That is pretty much what this game does with its annoying mayor game mechanic.  It sucks the fun right out of the game.

I've had this game for a little while and just got back into playing it.
It's honestly pretty fun to have to manage whether or not to sell and who to sell to based on the prices for oil at different companies, and the upgrades are pretty good as well. I can definitely say I recommend this game.

However, the wagon AI is [b]terrible[/b]. I've literally gotten spillages with [b]literally 40[/b] wagons and one rig with the pipe width boosted twice because the wagons don't care enough to stay near it or take any oil when it's almost at the top. This is the only reason I've had to get the timer upgrade, which extends the duration of time that a rig can be at full capacity before spilling.

If the wagon AI is improved slightly so that they're more aware of what rigs are producing the most oil, the game would be a bit more enjoyable, although it is very enjoyable already.

OMG I finally found out how to become mayor in expert mode, although I have grown to hate the game so much I'm not sure I will even bother.

In case you were wondering how to beat expert mode, you have to buy all the stock as soon as possible.
The AI are so much better than you that you can not hope to get enough money to buy them out at the end of the game. With this method you will have 50% stock near the end of the third area.

As for why I hate the game, it's the AI. 
(Also the game is repetitive and somewhat shallow, but you can beat normal and expert mode in around 20 hours so hopefully you will finish playing before you get sick of it.)
The AI do not make mistakes. Which means that in order to win, NO MISTAKES ALLOWED.
Did you find a gas pocket too late in the level ?
Did you have a slow start due to suboptimal pipe layout?
Did you have any spillage?
Did you make any mistake that cost you money?
Pause the game, stop the game from steam, then reopen the game from steam so you can try again.
If you do not retry a level you failed to optimize earnings, the AI will kick your butt so bad you will never catch up.
This makes an already repetitive game turn into a tedious grind to maximize earnings.

TLDR: Unless you are happy losing on expert mode, you may not enjoy the later half of the time you spend on this game.

Turmoil is an okay game that tries to be too much and the different aspects of the game come into conflict with each other and reduce the enjoyment of the experience.

The base level of the game is relatively well refined.  The goal is to extract as much of the oil from a randomly generated map and sell it for the best price possible.  There are various tools and strategies that you will gain along the way that help you do this.  I won't say this is perfect because there are some flaws but generally this part of the game is fine and there is the option to play the game just like this in single level mode or the weekly challenge.

The next level of the game is a sort of tycoon sim/role play that takes place in an arcade style town.  This part is really terrible but you will only run into it in the campaign modes.  This allows you to develop technology that will help you extract more oil from each individual level.  Since this is the worst part of the game it also allows me to show how this part interferes with the base oil extraction part of the game.  For whatever reason many of the techs you research require a fee in the town to research and then again on each oil field you chose to use them in.  This makes sense in the real world where better tech may cost more.  The problem is apparently your oil tycoon only has enough room on his wagon to the oil field for $2000 each year.  So despite having money in the bank in the town, you can't actually afford to buy the upgrades until well into the year.  And to do that you probably had to sell your early gains for below market value or take out loans with obscene interest rates (again despite having thousands of dollars if not much more in the bank that you can't use for no reason other than the game says you can't).

So basically the reason the game is holding your money hostage is the third level of the game is a "competition" against 3 AI to buy 50% of the mayor's shares in the town (government corruption xD).  This part of the game randomly pops up about half way through the second stage (of 4) in the campaign.  Every year you have to bid on a random percent of the shares and whoever bids the most wins them.  At the end you need that 50% to win the game.  That's right the win condition for a game advertised as a oil tycoon sim is to literally buy your way into the mayorship of a town surrounded by land that you have spent the last however many years depleting of oil.

In the end I am rating this mediocre game a thumbs down because I felt the challenge of the game came from the artificial constraints imposed by the developers ($2000 to start each year, time limited for both drilling and selling the oil, the need to buy something completely useless to the rest of the game to "win," among others).  The game is also very repetitive.  Each of the 4 areas have like 10 different rounds where you do literally the same thing but the map resources are randomly placed differently.  Despite giving the appearance that you should be able to optimize oil extraction, the constraints on time and money make it impossible to actually do this which adds to the frustration.

Fun casual game.  Doesn't require a lot of time to play.  Lots of replay value.

[h1]Preamble[/h1]

A good casual management game. It's not insanely difficult but it's a challenge to perfect your gameplay. It can quickly become repetitive, there's room for improvement to make the gameplay less mundane overtime as quickly as it does, but it's a decent game in its category.

If there's any category that comes to mind that [b]greatly[/b] lacks quality games, it's Mining games.
The only one that pops to mind as being an absolute A+ in the genre is [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/269110/Super_Motherload/?snr=1_1056_ajaxgetfilteredrecommendations_&curator_clanid=29162366]Motherload[/url].
I was hoping that Turmoil would be another [b]great[/b] game in this genre, but it isn't. Don't get me wrong, it is a good game, hence the positive review, but it's not a genre-defining game, it's great for a single play-through, [i]maybe[/i] a second one, but after that it becomes very stale.

I would also like to point out that just because it becomes a bit repetitive for me doesn't mean it has no replay-ability for anyone. This game may just as easily clique with you and you may think it has great replay-ability, which is great!

[h1]Gameplay and Mechanics[/h1]

The point of the game, and pretty much the only thing you do is dig for oil and manage that oil in terms of storing it and when you should sell it as prices go up and down. This can quickly become hectic, you can easily miss small windows of opportunity to sell your oil for a good price if you don't pay attention, and if you don't sell your oil in time you will run out of storage space and it can go south very quickly.
Good difficulty level, great management game-design, it's simple and entertaining.

The game, in my humble opinion, doesn't have much replay-ability because it becomes repetitive too quickly.
Playing through the main campaign is fine, I obviously liked it, but I couldn't really play much more after that without getting bored.
The reason it becomes repetitive, or at least became repetitive for [i]me[/i] is because you don't do much other than the core mechanic of digging oil and managing the oil, there's not really any other mechanics involved to freshen things up, it kinda just lacks in complexity.

Between every level you can buy and upgrade equipment and gain some skills, kind of.

The game [i]technically[/i] has replay-ability, there are different difficulty levels and you can complete challenges/achievements.

In terms of difficulty: It is not insanely difficult as I already mentioned, but it can be a tough challenge to really perfect your way of playing it, to be on top in every level.


[h1]Ending Words[/h1]

I played it for about 11 hours, and for the price tag, especially during a sale is well worth it for 11 hours of entertainment if you like this type of game. There were no bugs, the gameplay was smooth and all-around enjoyable for about 11 hours.

If you're hungry for a game in this category, I recommend it. If you're a bit skeptical, consider picking it up during a sale.


[h1]Curator page[/h1]

[i]If you liked this review or otherwise found it helpful in deciding whether or not to buy this game, feel free to follow [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/29162366/]my Curator page[/url].[/i]

Ever wonder what its like to be a modern day middle eastern country? Well do I have a game for you. This action packed thriller gives you a rollercoaster of emotions while you struggle to find the best prices as well as a reason to live. You can do just about anything, this includes extracting oil, selling oil, and curling up into a fetal position questioning your life choices. While I would like to recommend this game to any oil lovers out there I would just like to remind you that for the $10 you are going to spend on this game you can buy 100 feet of rainbow colored rope on amazon allowing you to go out fashionably.

well, 7 hours to finish and win the game...... 
seems short but I really value the "rare feature" allowing a game to be finished in today's gaming market.

All in all, a fun game, with good graphics and calm environmental music to set the mood.

Turmoil is a ‚Äútycoon‚Äù-style game for all ages and well worth the $6 or $7 US I spent. It‚Äôs a game about drilling for and selling oil. The drilling aspect is like a puzzle. You get an approximate location of where the oil is but sometimes your pipe doesn‚Äôt find the right spot. When your dowser alerts you to a new source, you have to decide between spending the money to build a new rig or laying new pipe to get to the source. Then there is the logistics. Do you have enough money to store your oil in a silo and bring it to market at the highest prices or do you have to sell at a lower price to raise some quick cash? Do you even have enough resources to transport your oil and avoid paying spilling fines? Sounds stressful, but it‚Äôs a very casual and relaxed game presented in a turn of the century (18th to 19th) US Western style. Good for adults who are looking for a quick game to play and good for kids to teach them about the basics of economics.

The music and the "very relaxing activity" on the marketing video made me want to try this game.
I don't remember the last time I was fooled so hard by a developer with bad intentions.
[b]EDIT:[/b] And if you see the developer comment, you'll notice how they completely ignored the complaint about their misguided marketing and changed the direction of the discussion. Now it's CLEAR it was intended misguided marketing.

You start the game: a Leaderboards right out of the bat, so you can compare you Digital P***s Size (commonly known as DPS) to other players.
Look the Settings menu to try and disable it? HA-HA. NO CHANCE.

Now, start campaign and select a player out of four. Remember the other 3? They are your computer opponents.

Ended drilling an area? Compare how you did to all 3 of them. EVERY. SINGLE. TIME.

Want to become the mayor? I hope you got the hang of the game, because EVERY SINGLE TIME before drilling, dispute in a F-king auction for shares.

Want to try a relaxing mode where you are just playing against yourself, trying to get the hang of things? YOU CAN'T.

If you are looking for a management game with a good mix of strategy, depth, a sprinkle of luck, and competitive sense, this is your game. Otherwise, hit the "Ignore" button. You won't miss anything of importance.

I regret ever coming across this game on Steam. That's one developer blacklisted for me.
