[u]In short:[/u] It's a very simplified oil drilling sim with many flaws. I love the concept and atmosphere. Unfortunately the implementation is quite lacking. Gameplay is very shallow and repetitive and the UI sometimes annoying. There are many strange design decisions which ultimately drained all the fun out of the experience for me. Personally, I wouldn't even buy it on sale, although the price seems fair.

[u]In long:[/u] The basic [b][u]gameplay[/u][/b] revolves around drilling for oil. Each level is a 2D slice through the ground. Prospectors indicate oil deposits so you can place your oil rigs and drag straight lines to drill into the ground. Once you hit an oil deposit it will be slowly pumped up where you pick it up with horse wagons and store it for later or sell it.
Several limitations provide a challenge: Levels generally last for 12 months before they automatically end (about 10 minutes of real time). During this period the level slowly scrolls upwards, revealing deeper parts. Each level starts you with a limited budget of $2,000 and literally every action costs money. There is limited space above ground and sometimes rocks inhibit drilling
There are a lot of different [b][u]mechanics[/u][/b] at play, especially in the campaign mode meta-layer visualized as an old-timey Western town. Buy promising plots in land auctions, spend profits on gear upgrades, bribe officials for bonuses on the next level. Once in the level you need to prospect, drill, and manage space, time and cost at the same time. The main economic mechanic is bound to the constantly fluctuating sell prices at two refineries. Sell now so you can invest or store for later to make a bigger profit? On later levels you can find diamonds (may extend playtime on a level or reveal good plots) or gas deposits (can temporarily boost prices). Bonus cash is handed out for draining every deposit and for finishing early. Finally the over-all goal of the campaign is to own a majority stake in the town, which you can pick up during share auctions.

Sounds promising, doesn't it? Unfortunately the actual gameplay is [b][u]shallow and flawed[/u][/b] in many ways:
My biggest gripe by far is how [u]repetitive[/u] the game is. Apart from the introduction of rocks and gas halfway through the campaign of 40 levels, you're essentially replaying the same level over and over again. The campaign is pretty much just a framework for a level generator. Don't get me wrong, level generators are always welcome, but here it leads to every level feeling the same. Limitations of money and space make you stick to the same build order and building layouts.
The [u]scaling and progression[/u] are way off. All the many upgrades and cool mechanics have little impact for most of your playtime. Each level starts with the same amount of money, which is usually enough for only one rig. There is no way to accelerate the early game, so you have to suffer through it dozens of times, never giving you a satisfying feeling of having outgrown your early days as a small oil driller. There are no passive production boosts at all - first you pay to unlock an upgrade, then you pay to have it installed each level. Example: Unlocking drill speed does not make drilling faster unless you pay an additional $500 on each individual drilling rig. Often you don't end up buying the upgrades at all. Once you can afford them, they're often not cost effective anymore for the limited time remaining. Levels don't even get larger or more intricate. They always scroll up at the same excuciatingly slow speed, so finishing early sometimes risks missing a tiny pocked of oil at the very bottom, which kills your full-clear bonus. Said bonus is also sometimes denied by the wonky liquid physics - tiny amounts of oil and gas in the same pipe can take months to clear out for some reason.
The impact of [u]randomness[/u] is too big for my taste. Levels vary wildly in the amount and accessibility of oil deposits and how good of a level you're going to get is essentially random for most of the game. Sometimes prospectors ignore giant oil deposits near the surface and instead indicate tiny bubbles underneath rock. The random level generation is good for replayability, but can also completely shut you out with rocks. All the auctions are essentially random as to where and how heavily the AI will bid. There's also a wide range between incredibly useful and utterly useless NPCs who show up at the saloon to offer one-time bonuses for the next level.
The AI is pretty competitive unless you know exactly what you're doing, so the game clearly expects a degree of [u]optimization[/u] by the player. But it doesn't give you the proper tools to do so. There's a prominently displayed price per unit of oil, but you'll never see an actual amount anywhere. How much oil fits in a wagon or a silo? Will the capacity upgrade pay off or should I just sell overflow? How much is left in the deposit and what is the through-put of my level 2 pipes? You can painstakingly reverse-engineer ratios and rough estimates, but frustratingly the game expects you to optimize your business on guesswork.

Unfortunately the problems don't stop with gameplay and extend into the [b][u]user interface[/u][/b]: Inbetween almost every level of the campaign two auctions (land and stock) take place. The game will not let you advance without completing them, which takes at least 6 clicks through 2 different interfaces per auction, not to speak of watching "riveting" AI bid-wars for several seconds. If they are mandatory, please just streamline the process. Reminder pop-ups without shortcuts are just annoying. Speaking of the stock auction - what a terrible concept! It's a kind of Dutch auctions where a huge wheel visualizes the price ticking down. It's partly a reaction game, but it boils down to gambling, as the AI is essentially bidding randomly. It always starts with the highest networth, so if someone has loads of cash, you're watching for 10 seconds before the price is even remotely competitive. The devs probably know how terrible it is, since one of the paid DLC features is an alternate stock auction. Not sure why they feel fixing the main game should cost money.
A few minor UI gripes: The tutorial about many essential mechanics only unlocks several levels in and each explanation costs in-game money (admittedly a tiny amount, but the concept is ridiculous). The very helpful prospector NPC just vanishes once you buy a plot, leaving me wondering where he was for most of the game as I always bought plots before visiting the saloon. It's also probably not the smartest move to have click-drag from a valve be drilling and clicking on a valve be toggling it for $150. More than once I misclicked my first drill, costing me $300 of my $2,000 starting funds.

In terms of [b][u]technical aspects[/u][/b] the game gets passing marks. The menu features separate volume sliders and many language options, but just a few pre-definied resolutions (they're sensible though). Windowed mode works well. Concerning the [b][u]audio-visiual experience[/u][/b] the music is decent. The sound effects are generally passable, with a few slightly jarring exceptions. It's a bit plain, but I actually like the visual style of the game.

Fair disclaimer: I do not own the DLC and have not played the expert mode campaign. They may very well address a few of my gripes. But in [b][u]conclusion[/u][/b] I found Turmoil to be way too tedious and repetitive. The game has a great atmosphere and theme, but does very little with it. It's neither a simulation, nor an arcade game. Because of the small amount of unique content and the many design flaws the game ended up frustrating me more than entertaining me. I would never pay full price for it. At 50% off on sale your milage may vary, but I frankly enjoyed myself too little to justify even that more sensible price tag.

Turmoil is a good game for me because I find it very funny to play, with quick results being seen, either when loosing... or winning! 
Graphic design, even if being simple, is very representatvive of what I had in mind about the oil rush in the United States during the Wild West in the 19th century. 
The different actions to do during the game, once again even if it seems simple in apparence, are also very representative of what I had in mind regarding the management of petrol fields exploitation and towns during the Wild West.
In campaign mode, which is what I started the game with, years of petrol exploitation appear like "moving paintings" and are not too long (it is even speed possible to speed them when necessary). 
With the help of automatic saves between each "painting" (I thought of each year as a painting since the game automatically provides you with a screen capture at the end of a year when giving you results and charts), I can play Turmoil just the way I want it, depending on the time I have for playing:
- a few "paintings"/years for my immediate enjoyment, and then I go and do something else, 
- or a big rush till the end of the campaign when I am in a mood to always do better than the previous year; the game can really become addictive, especially when I feel that it is one of my good days!
Of course, since it is a construction and management simulation, it could quickly become annoying. However, each campaign appears to be really different to me because if each petrol fields are randomly created at the beginning of a "painting", there are so many ways to break through difficulties for exploiting them with less or more costs that it is always a challenge for me to try to do better than before.  
At last, I can add that the music does help me to have a good immersive experience each time I play Turmoil. If it is of course in a western style, there are enough different soundtracks played depending on actions being done that it really breaks the monotony which could occur for me with such kind of games.

Also, they don't seem to be very good at all because they would never make more than $10,000 in one game and barely ever bought the upgrades so it really just got easier and easier as you went along. One of them bought one upgrade for the entire game.

If you are looking for a short indie game that will keep you entertained for a few hours, go for it. If you want a game to invest in that you can play for a a couple hundred hours, there are plenty of cheap games out there that will satisfy this need.

Before I bought Turmoil, I think back to the times I played Oiligarchy; searching for oil, bribing government official, supporting foreign dictatorship so that you can militarize the country and ravage their native lands. And I figured, for around $3 when it's on sale it must be a steal, yet somehow, this game manages to disappoint even that low expectation. Maybe because the aforementioned game is a free flash game and offers so much more imo. But about 2 levels in I've already felt that I've seen everything there is to see. And into the second area the game introduce 2 new mechanics, neither of which I'm too excited about.

What you need to know before going into Turmoil is this. This game have too much RNG factor to be considered a good strategy game. Don't go into this game with the intent to maximize your production. Play this game like an arcade game, like angry birds or something. The money you earn is like a high score. You'll get a high score in this level, and you'll get another one in the next level. This high score may or may not allow you to buy some upgrades. But think of those purchases like bonuses. If you think of this game like an arcade game, then the RNG factor will seem far less punishing than it is. And the content won't feel as lacking and repetitive because it's just an arcade game like candy crush or Angry girds.

This land is rich with oil, I can feel it!

Three years late to game and possessing faint memories of a gameplay video I watched way back when, it is finally time to make a name for myself in the oil business. We all missed the oil rush, but with Turmoil you can relive that period of time and cash in with that liquid gold.

After hearing how much oil the ground can hold, you come to the very town that happens to be surrounded by many plots of land holding oil. However, you are not the only oil entrepreneur that heard about this and decided to travel to this town. Three others will compete alongside you to make the most out of this opportunity. Once you pick your desired character, arrive in town with your starter money, and receive the mayor‚Äôs gift of a free plot of land, you are ready to get drillin‚Äô.

Turmoil‚Äôs gameplay is simple, but difficult to master. Before you set out to bring the oil up to the surface, you must get the land with it, and to get that you must have the lease. This section is called the land auction and everyone has a chance at winning land while also outbidding others. As everyone continues to drill oil, the land already purchased will show their oil yields and suggests that the land around them will also yield around that amount. Would you risk outbidding a competitor or go for a different one?

Apart from the first two warm-up rounds, each land lease lasts a year so you only have a finite time to bring up the oil. On top of this, you can only take $2,000 with you. So first things first, finding the oil. Dowsers are the first available source of locating oil (later on you can get moles and scanners), and possibly the most often used, but will not show where exactly it is, just that it will be under them. You can then build a rig, drill down until it hits a pocket of oil or misses it entirely as you drill back up, and buy a horse that can transport the oil.

Where do you sell the oil to make a profit while also being able to buy more resources? Well, two companies, Left Inc. and Right Inc. which are located on their respected sides, will compete for your business. Both Left and Right Inc. will fluctuate in their prices as time goes on and if you sell oil to them consecutively. To get the most out of the oil, you need to keep an eye on these prices. If you sell too much to one company, you might find yourself embarrassingly selling oil for 49 cents, but if you wait too long the high price will stop increasing.

Despite how easy this may seem, a lot is up to strategy. As you drill for oil, your rigs can easily turn on you if you‚Äôre not paying attention to them. If too much oil is not being shifted to the horses, the rigs will get blocked up and eventually spill. This will give you a hefty spillage fee by the end of the year if you react too slowly. The Left and Right Inc. might also not be in your favor as no prices live up to your taste, or perhaps you‚Äôre waiting to use the gas to your advantage, at that moment. To avoid spillage, you can set down silos to store the oil till the price is right. Make sure to keep storage space open so horses can keep storing it, but keep an eye on the date, as December can quickly sneak up to you as you wait to sell. It can quickly turn into a race to sell everything before you are forced to leave all that oil in the silos dashing all their hopes and dreams of being sold.

At the end of the year, you will get statistics on how it went like your spending and profit. There are also bonuses that you can get to earn extra money. You will get bonuses for depleting all the oil, selling all the oil, depleting all the gas, and closing your lease early (which will also net you a lease payback). So if you find yourself finished before the year is up, no need to wait it out.

The town isn‚Äôt just for show, but also hold valuable resources once you get back every year. There are shops that offer upgrades to help you while you drill oil which can range from upgrading existing equipment to make them more efficient to giving you a whole new equipment (which will also have upgrades to make them more effective). This new equipment provides other ways to reveal oil pockets, which are moles, who randomly reveal tiles, and scanners, which automatically reveal whatever is in the scanner circle. More upgrades are added as you get to a new area that will have a different conditions. Such as an area having rocks that require you to upgrade your drill if you want to drill through them or needing moles and a specific upgrade to pick up diamonds if they show up by chance. You also have Daphne‚Äôs, which is a saloon where you talk to various people that you can... generously donate money to as they return a favor. These offers can get Left or Right Inc. to not go under a certain price, give you a discount on spillage fees, or even lower interest rates. If you find yourself low on cash, the bank can also give you a loan, but you have to pay them back by the end of the year no matter how big of a loan you take out.

Around half way through, an interesting prospect turns up as the winning condition is revealed. The mayor is selling the town stocks Dutch auction style and whoever has 50% will become the new mayor. All you have to do is watch the price go down to either you press the buy button or your competitor does. Those who have less than 50% will be kicked out of town (if no one has 50%, whoever has less gets kicked out and their shares will be auctioned till someone does), and if that‚Äôs you, well, you lost the campaign. This is really the only aspect of Turmoil that I disliked as I found this too random. The AI can pay more for a share that was less than the last round or outright use all of their money immediately. The only hope is to keep your money above the AI and go to land auctions first in hopes that they spend their money on upgrades before the stock auction.

If you do become mayor, there is a special plot of land that the old mayor will point you towards. Giving you a nice, and hectic, end to a campaign.

The Heat is On DLC review 

Verdict

Turmoil may be simple, but it holds an addicting management sim that requires you to be strategic to get the most profit out of each land lease. A lot of thought went into how to make drilling oil more than that through the many ways you can go about it, how the areas differ other than the background, and the upgrades you choose to pick up. While also having you manage your money in a way that you can gain a profit during a land lease and later afford auctions. If you so choose, replayability is high as each campaign varies due to plots being randomly generated, ability take part in weekly challenges and being able to generate single levels by seeds. I really had fun as I relaxed, occasionally freaked out over oil spilling, and thinking of ways to get more and more profit than my other competitors.

Before going deeper in the review I want to say that it makes sad to say that I bought this game some months back and after 2 hours I requested a refund. I wanted to support the developer but I have to say that I find the game way too over priced. 

[b] [u] Review: [/u] [/b]

[list]
 [*]Gameplay
     The main goal of the game is to buy land, pieces of land, hoping to get the piece with the most oil/gas/minerals from an auction done before each level. You are trying to outbid the game's AI characters or making them over bid for a piece of land. After you buy land you get in for a limited time in which you have to extract most if not all of the oil and other diamonds you may find in some levels. After that you go to the town and buy upgrades for your equipment, keeping in mind to leave enough money to buy land in the next round. This is basically the whole game.
 [*]Graphics
    The graphics are nice, the animations smooth. The portraits show enough to tell the characters appart without going in too much details. 
 [*]Sound/Music
    A nice soundtrack though after some time it grew repetitive and somewhat annoying. Sound effects are exaclty what you'd expect, not too much but not too little either.
 [*]Story
     There is no story in the game. There are dialogs with some characters in the game's town
 [*]Replay value
     There is not much, for me at least. I think it's a nice game, but there is not enough content in the game to make you come back and play it time after time for hours.
 [*]Price
     Full price of 10 euro not worth it for me. It is kind of overpriced for the amount of content and replayability it offers. There are a lot of good games out there you can get with half of that. Even with a 50% off I find it kinda too much given that in an hour or so you would know everything there is to know and have unlocked almost anything there is to unlock.
[/list]

[b]Overall[/b]
I found the game nice and amusing, but after an hour or so I found it too be too repetitive for me. I actually refunded the game with a heavy heart, being an Indie game. I'm sorry for the bad things I wrote about the game but even bad comments are constructive to help the Developer become better with each released game.

I would recomend, although, you give the game a try if you think the things listed above are not so bad.

While a decent time waster and all around basic sim/management game, I cannot recommend this game at all. It's extremely unbalanced and nonsensical. The basic laws of supply and demand are non-existent. There is no rhyme or reason for the prices of oil to be fluctuating and there is nothing to base your strategy on other than going in blind and winging it. For those who've never played this is nothing less than frustrating while you get stomped by the AI. I don't mind being beaten but when the game has a function that it simply doesn't tell me about or tells me about it poorly then that's when it's aggrivating. As for the unbalanced part of the game. The spillage penalties. I get being penalized for spilling out oil that could have other wise be sold but this is basically adding insult to injury. This is the feature that prompted me to write this review. I paid nearly $60k in spillage fees when without those fees I would have profited $30k. What a waste of time and effort. There were other levels earlier that I spilled WAY more and wasn't charged that much in spillage. If this increases as you advance in the game then the game should tell you that. 

In conclusion it's a decent time killer but not worth $10.00. Maybe a $3 or possibly on sale at the $4.99 Summer Sale that I got it at. Then there is the DLC. Really? Does this game REALLY need DLC? I thought this would be a nifty little lightweight tycoon game. Color me disappointed.

Now, before you all get the wrong idea, the game isn't bad at all. I went into this game with the wrong expectations I think and therefore just didn't enjoy it very much, the game is pretty good but maybe it just doesn't resonate with me. For what you get, the price is about right.

So I went into this expecting a lot more than what was actually in it, maybe different types of drills, different types of oil or some kind of oil processing element with some crazy upgrades. I thought there would be more parts to this game. However, what happens is the following:

1. Find Oil using either dude/mole/scanner
2. Put pump above oil and drill down to oil
3. Buy a few horses, direct them to the company with the best price
4. Wait

Then you just do that, again and again and again... Once you've got the initial setup going with 2 or 3 oil pumps, you usually just sit around not doing very much until the game ends. I found myself setting things up and then just holding down the 'x' key for speeding the game up until the year ends. It's fun, for like the first 5 or 6 times you do it, and then there's not really much else and it gets a bit stale. 

Also, for me a lot of the upgrades felt a bit 'eh', I bought bigger pipes because that seemed pretty obvious for more cash, but I couldn't even notice any difference to my pipes when I then tested it out. The game introduces rocks to make mining harder too, this however didn't make it more fun or add much to the game, it just meant I then had to burn a load of cash at the shop to ignore the rocks... I then bought better horses to move oil faster, turns out that even though you payed tonnes for the upgrade, you still need to pay a big chunk of money every time you then want to use them.

Meh, the game was alright. It got repetitive pretty quickly and even owning the DLC didn't interest me in playing more of it. Feels like it could be an awesome flash game, but a bit lacking for a full title release.
Starts of fun but after a while it can get pretty repetive

Awesome Oil Exploration Simulator!

This is a pretty fun little game.

In each level, you find and dig up oil and try to get the best price for it.

It's all set old-timey USA, and it's all surprisingly non-industrial, for oil mining. Oil is located either by men with divining rods (sticks) or trained moles (as in, the animal). Or, magical scanning things. It is easily and cleanly drilled using pipes (sometimes with the help of gas to speed it up). Oil is transported by horse-drawn cart, the skies are always blue, the fields are always green. The music always acoustic.

The only nod to environmentalism in this game is... you get a hefty fine if you spill oil, from mining it quicker than your little horses can cart away.

All a pleasant dream, very much removed from reality. But that's ok, because it's just the setting for a light-hearted game.

At the end of each level, your score is pitted against 3 AI opponents, who will also bid against you in selecting land to mine and stocks to buy, giving the game an overall board-game feel.

I picked up Turmoil for 1.99 USD. It was definitely worth it.

It's a good strategic game, where you manage oil extraction. You play each individual level, where you plop down rigs, silos and pipes. You decide when and which company to sell oil to, based on prices. You must decide when to strategically raise the prices during a level through natural gas. 
Once you finish a level, you return to the campaign overview, where you make your way through different drilling areas, purchase upgrades that make your oil drigging outfit more efficient, bid on land and later in the game, town stocks.

Good decisions that result in good profits roll over to the campaign mode and allow you to purchase upgrades before your competition. Know how to play, and you can slowly snowball into a surefire victory towards the end of the campaign.
It's satisfying that way, knowing your actions have put you in a good position towards the end. 
The gameplay is deep and strategic.

The game has replayability. Once you finish the campaign once, characters gain abilities, and you can have a go at it again. Each level is different, and each campaign will play out differently.
The campaign doesn't grow stale thanks to the fact that the game introduces more mechanics over the course of 4 different areas. Upgrades, rocks that you must drill around and gas.

The art style is unique and well done. It has it's own unique flair to it.

Overall, a fantastic game for it's price if you pick it up on sale like I did. Might be worth buying too if you're swimming in money like if you were an oil tycoon in Turmoil. For 18 hours of play so far, I've spent 0.111 cents an hour on this game. 
That's good entertainment value.

[h1]TL;DR at Bottom[/h1]
[b]Let me know what you thought of this review in the comments below![/b]

[h1]Verdict :[/h1]
[b][i]Quiet, relaxing, and surprisingly cutthroat; Recommended Purchase[/i][/b]

[h1]Work Em' Dead[/h1]
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1289612694&fileuploadsuccess=1
A ravenous earthly shower befalls you, inching away at both your sanity and your health. With blues skies above you and the satisfying crunch of rock and dirt beneath, you raise your pick and get hunting. Not for gems, of course, those are frivolties for a higher class, one you don‚Äôt count yourself apart of. . . yet. Instead you hunt for gold, but not of the metallic variety, instead for that which is ebony in color and liquid in form. Oil. Black gold. Whatever you call it, you know that upon your timely return to town it‚Äôs going to buy you everything you could possibly desire and more. Except in Turmoil, you don‚Äôt play as the basic laborer slaving away day after day for naught but pennies on the dollar: you play as his boss. Turmoil is a weird game for me to categorize because it‚Äôs definitely management, but not management of people. You oversee the creation and workings of various oil pumps and that which flows so freely out of them; while yes that does mean you‚Äôll be managing people, that isn‚Äôt really what Turmoil is about. It‚Äôs more about the hunt for oil itself, which is an idea that I thought would prove too shallow to make a game, at least when I initially began. However, they really utilized the idea in all its forms and facets, making for a game that still isn‚Äôt too deep, but regardless stands much less shallow than I expected. There‚Äôs a rather humorous bit of irony to be found in a game entirely focused on digging that stands shallow in gameplay. Regardless of that, I still think that the devs managed to flesh it out as much as can be done, which is admirable whether they‚Äôre a small studio or not. The key mechanics of the game are so enjoyable that it doesn‚Äôt matter near as much that they actually have much more. Not to say a content drought, pardon the pun, is a good thing, but it‚Äôs pushed out of focus by the extremely fun main mechanics. And those mechanics are extremely satisfying, managing your own little oil tycoon and slowly pushing all your competitors out of town and straight to hell. It does get old though, not very quickly but it gets old all the same, which is why I found myself playing for only a few hour long bursts. Turmoil is a game that you can just throw on, mute the audio, and listen to your favorite podcast or youtube channel while you slowly drain the earth of oil, drop by drop.

[h1]Grapes of Wrath[/h1]
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1289608966&fileuploadsuccess=1
There‚Äôs literally no story here, other than that you‚Äôre an exorbitantly rich guy looking to become exponentially richer through the excavation and wholesale selling of sweet sweet oil. I‚Äôm glad they didn‚Äôt opt for some weird story, forcefully shoveled into your face like a parent trying to force their kid to eat veggies, because it puts the focus entirely on the gameplay. Thankfully that‚Äôs a good thing, because the gameplay is both organic and extremely fun. It‚Äôs mainly centered around two things: discovering where the oil is, and getting it out of the ground and flowing into your pockets. The former can be surprisingly difficult, because the oil randomly spawns depending on the rating of the land you purchased. Yes, you need to actually purchase the land through entertaining little auctions while you‚Äôre in town. These typically involve you picking a lucrative piece of land, and then promptly watching the three AI competitors scramble to steal it from you, driving the price up rapidly in the process. Later in the game you enter into auctions for a percentage of town stock, slowly but surely buying up the town, in the most literal sense. I absolutely love these little mini-feuds between the characters, because they start to get extremely personal; resulting in you forming rivalries and bonds of hatred with the others. I had to take a step back and just laugh at myself when I started yelling at Ricardo because the bastard had yet again stolen 4% of the stock right out from under me. These little rivalries are extremely fun not only because they make the game more personal, but also because they create an organic sense of fun that‚Äôs never the same as before. The gameplay does that as well, and I love how difficult they made it to actually find the oil, much less to dig it all up and get it to market. Because of that, you actually need to use all of the different additional side items, as opposed to just being able to wing it and guess where the oil‚Äôs at. These little side items, like a mole that digs up tiny spots of dirt or a sonar scan that clears a massive circle of dirt, make the discovering experience significantly more fun. That‚Äôs a good thing because without it you would just be doing the same three actions over and over again; get a dowser to find the oil, set up pumps and wells, then transport it all to market. Instead you still end up doing those three things, but you do them in fun little ways. Yes, you‚Äôre still just finding oil, but you‚Äôre doing it with moles and sonar scans as opposed to just throwing down a dowser and waiting for the results. I‚Äôm sure I‚Äôm repeating myself, but I can‚Äôt emphasize enough that while you are in essence doing the exact same thing every time, the different ways in which you can do it make for gameplay that doesn‚Äôt get old.

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
It's never been this cheap nor this fun to bludgeon your enemies to death with the righteous baton of capitalism, worth your money and your oil.

[h1]If you found this review helpful or entertaining then feel free to leave a comment and join my Steam Curator Group at  [url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/9577715-Mudkips-Gaming/]Mudkips Gaming![/url]

Turmoil is a 1800s fantasy oil prospector game. You play as 1 of 4 oil prospectors drilling for oil in a 2D plane. You start with $20,000 and use $2000 per game as startup cost.

Gameplay-wise, it's just using your mouse to hire a dowser to find the oil, build your oil wells, drill down to the oil, build silos and get wagons to transport the oil to the refineries. You look at the price that the refinery is offering you and you decide if you wish to sell your oil by clicking on the arrows. If you don't want to sell your oil, you can store the oil in a silo and wait for the right price. But beware, if you don't collect the oil in a timely manner, your oil well can spillover due to the pressure. You can also buy upgrades for recovering the oil faster, storing more oil and scanning for the oil. You can also take loans and bid for land plots to drill for more oil.

Conclusion, I'm not really sure if this is doing it for me but I really don't enjoy the ridiculousness of this game. It might be some guesswork but in reality there are a lot of scientific methods for finding oil, like studying the age of the rocks at different depths (geology) and coring. The dowsing and moles are kind of a WTF moment for me.

[h1][b]PROS[/b][/h1]
1. It's Simple to Pick Up
It's like Cookie Clicker but you only need to click when to sell your oil.

[h1][b]CONS[/b][/h1]
1. Mysticism for Finding Oil
Dowsing to find oil was pushing it. When I saw the mole used to dig underground, I just got severely turned off.

2. Boring Gameplay
At a certain point of time, it's just clicking on whether you want to sell the oil.

What a great little game. 

You play against 3 AI oil tycoons. The aim is to make money and eventually become the Mayor of the town. The game is split into two phases. 

The town phase sees you purchase and upgrade your equipment, sell diamonds, gain advantages by talking with saloon patrons, buy shares and select the next parcel of land to drill on. 

The mining phase has you explore your land and drill for oil, gas and rare diamonds. You can do this in several different ways. Using humans, animal, electronics or even pot luck. As you collect oil you either need to store it or sell to one of two companies. This phase lasts between 3-12 months (usually 12) and you must sell your oil before the end of the phase.  Each block of land is random so finding the oil is different each time. 

There are quite a few different upgrades that cater to whatever play style you choose. 

Well worth it.

Become the oil baron and try to become mayor of the town after you and three other oil barons try to empty out the whole map of oil. After that think about why the mayor wanted to sell his position.

Overall I enjoyed this game and at less than 5$ I'd say it was worth the money. It's a relaxing game where you drill for oil and compete against three AI characters. 

However there are some cons you start noticing later in the game.

- You buy upgrades but most of them still require you to purchase the upgrade during each 'level' while drilling for oil. Everything is so expensive it's basically not worth it in the actual levels themselves unless you come across a very large store of oil and need to drill through rock or increase the pipe flow. I would much prefer that those upgrades are permanent additions like with the Dowsers. It would increase replayability since you could choose different upgrade paths along the way.

- More to the point above the NPCs don't seem to buy any upgrades so despite them sometimes making 5k or under in profit per level they always have stacks of cash to blow at the share auction. I'm currently halfway through the last zone and I've seen an NPC purchase one upgrade which was the drill. Maybe they do purchase upgrades, and I've just been missing it. They just always end up having way more cash despite making way less profit consistently.

- Not enough micro-management - when the price of oil increases at Left or Right you want to sell as much of your oil as quickly as possible yet selling carts will go empty an oil rig and go to sell with a nearly empty cart instead of filling it from a silo, or emptying a rig and then filling at a silo. It gets frustrating at the end of every year when you have so many carts going to sell barely any oil and you end up with an entire upgraded silo of unsold oil.

Overall, at <$5.00 it's a good game.  However the developers could improve it by:

+having multiple save games.  Currently there are no saves other than the autosave back at town
+The stock market seems like a tacked on victory condition.  It's an incredibly annoying system.
+penalties for spillage are far too severe.  At the very least there should be options for reducing the penalty, it's not enough that you're already losing oil to the ground that you need to be losing thousands in profit?  This was set in the 19th century, there was no greenpeace-  who's fining me $8000 for a bit of spill!?!
+Allowing mod support (even if it's just an ini file to change variables such as SPILL penalties).

Those issues aside, and considering the price, it's worth a few bucks.

Turmoil is a cohesive and seemingly bug free experience that was worth the dicsounted price from the Steam sale, but given its somewhat limited replayability, probably not worth a whole lot more.  It's basically everything I can expect (and maybe a little more) from any low budget indie game.

Coming from playing fast-action games, this game caught me by surprise. What was more surprising is that I actually spent $4.50 on it. Low and behold, it's well worth the price.

Pros:
-Simple, but requires strategy and some money-management. Unless you want to repay the high-interest loans of the bank!
-Easy to play, enough trial and error to keep the game fun.
-Replayability: Honestly, after I beat the campaign, which took about 7 hours, you could play it again on a more difficult mode, with every character having a special ability to help balance out the difficulty.

Cons: 
-Purchasing Stock: Slight spoilers, this makes the game a bit more difficult. However, you can just simply quit and reload until you get a decent price.
-Price: I bought this on sale for 55% off for $4.49. That is a fair price. The normal price is $9.99 which is a bit steep IMHO.

A fun little game where you play an oil tycoon squaring off against three others in a bid to force your enemies to drink your milksha... I mean, in a bid to get the most cash by drilling for oil and to become mayor.

Bid on a parcel of land, buy your upgrades and get out there and dig for oil! The gameplay is simple and reasonably addictive, forming a mixture of careful management, guesswork and calculating risk. You send out your dowsers to look for oil in the depths of the earth. Plonk your rig where you reckon the good stuff is, and send down a pipe. But oil isn't always easy to find. Sometimes its sunk deep, or behind a partial barrier of rock. That's where the trained mole comes in, diving joyously into the earth and uncovering little bits of the map beneath you. Once you've started tapping the sweet black gold you better get some wagons moving to the buyer's depot. Better be careful though, if the oil spurts up too thick and fast you'll get fines for spillage. Or the market might crash, forcing you to store the product in silos until prices recover. It's a neat little balancing act, but never too frantic. 

In between digging for oil you get returned to town to buy upgrades, grease the palms of the odd helpful official and bid for shares in becoming mayor. All good clean fun. Except oil isn't clean. It's a filthy business.

This game is good for one more turn shennanigans. However, after completing it a couple of times I can imagine you won't want to return to it for a long time. There's not overly much to it. But that's fine. The price fits the amount of gameplay you'll find in this package. I imagine you'll get a good ten hours out of it, not bad for seven pounds or so. 

Any flaws? Well, it could do with a little more personality when it comes to your rivals. You don't really feel any comedy antagonism against them. They just say a few ho-hum stock phrases and politely try to outdo you. You never feel like you're in too much competition against anyone. Which is a shame. The odd pop up bit of dialogue between missions with them twirling their moustaches or brandishing their parasols at you might be amusing. The game could also do with some random events or periodic temporary mechanics to keep things from getting stale. Perhaps subsidence knocking out oil-rigs for a time until they can be shored back up. A passel of free-herders running cattle across the map. A travelling snake oil merchant giving your crew a little mystery bottle of 'pep' to move their horses faster.
  
But all in all Turmoil is a perfectly fine game. Nothing earth-shaking but good fun for a few idle evenings of play. It's the definition of a good 'seven out of ten' game, one I can cheerfully recommend.
Its a good game and takes only a few hours to complete but you can play it again and again without become boring! It steal your time, just one round more... :D

To be clear, this game will appeal to the inner capitalist in all of us.  You must observe prices while spending money.  Leverage your resources and turn a profit!

A fun little time waster.  Somewhere between M.U.L.E. and the old C-64 game, Oil Barons.   

Each round has you buying land in an auction and then spending a season producing oil on that land.  Between rounds, you can upgrade elements to help you find and drill the oil more efficiently.  The oil wells are always randomized, and the drilling aspect is kind of clever.  The more you drill, the more information it reveals about the size of the well, but the more money you'll spend.  Placement between the two companies that buy your oil can affect how quickly you can sell it.   Suddenly Left is offering $2.00 a barrel, but your derricks are on the right.  So there's a little time management going on too.   The game is cleverly balanced, and a lot of fun.  Definitely worth the $10.

Turmoil is casual, cash management sim game where you are tasked with drilling for oil. The gameplay essentially comes in two parts: 1) finding and selling oil before a timer runs out and 2) using your profits to buy upgrades.

The "Finding and selling oil" gameplay, while fun, does becomes repetitive after awhile. The progression that comes from "using your profits to buy upgrades" sadly, mostly serves to boost things you already have access to. While the more unique upgrades, that could alter your gameplay, largely feel unnecessary.

With that said, I bought it at full price at launch due to the premise, which I thought was interesting, and ended up having a fun time for around a dozen hours. Despite the concerns mentioned above, I recommend it.

It's so hard to find a game that succesfully straddles the line between being zen enough to play when you don't have the energy for most games, yet still being engaging enough to keep you playing for hours at a time. Turmoil manages exactly that. You slowly watch your profits go up as you explore different plots of lands and drain them of oil, all the while trying to stay ahead of your competitors. It's a fun challenge to figure out which upgrades are worth investing in to maximise your profits. On top of that, you work your way through four different ground types, each with their own game mechanics that add some variety.

If you're a fan of management type games or just want a nice game to relax with, give this one a try!

If you're looking for a fun little time killer, this is a great little game.  The design and implementation is excellent.  You can see the devs put thought and work into balancing everything out.  Light on replayability, but that's not a killer at a low price point.

Reminds me a lot of an old flash game called Oiligarchy, which I used to have a lot of fun playing.

It's very exciting to look for oil deposits and trying to maximize your profits while working against the clock. The upgrade system is pretty decent for the most part, which keeps the game fun in the late game.

The auctions are really simple but fun enough without taking too much time of gameplay, very well done.

Overall I had a lot of fun playing this game, but it makes me a little bugged that it could be better.

The fact that you have to play the Easy mode campaign first to unlock the advanced AI is pretty frustrating, cause there is no challenge in the first 8 hours of game. It could easily kill the game for you.

Some upgrades are pretty underpowered too, like moles and diamonds, which leaves no room for different strategies.

The gas mechanic is by far the worse part for me. It's boring, it's not very sophisticated and it makes no sense at all, it feels completely out of place compared with the other mechanics.

With that said, I haven't finished the game because of the problems above, but I still had 18 hours of fun, which is a decent time for this kind of game.

I recommend it if it's on sale.

Turmoil is a casual simulation game based on the 19th century oil boom in North America. 



Turmoil's gameplay consists of drilling for oil and purchasing upgrades. The player will buy leases on land and drill for oil on said land. The players objective is to make as much money as possible by selling the oil to 2 rival company's. Players will have a variety of tools at their disposal, including; bigger pipes, larger silos, more carts to sell oil, scanners and even a pet mole. Money seems to be almost an issue in turmoil, if a player buys an expensive upgrade, and then drill on a plot of land with little oil, they could find themselves in the red.  


The art and sound design are both fantastic. The sound design is fun, lighthearted and overall, fir the game perfectly. The art style is cartoony but still  somewhat serous. The graphics and overall deal of the art fits the game flawlessly. Turmoil certainly did its art design right.


Turmoil does a lot right:


Many upgrade options 

Addictive 

Surprisingly fun

Looks and sounds great



Turmoil does do a few things badly: 

No difficulty settings 

Can be slow to start

Tends to be repetitive 

Lacks replayability  



Overall Turmoil is a fantastic game, It's well designed and quite a bit of fun. The price of $10.99 CND is a little steep but if picked up on sale, could be a fantastic buy for fans of casual games.

This game is fun. It is slightly better than an internet flash game. There is no story or character development. It is a 10 minute minigame that is repeated with slightly added complexity at the end. I highly recommend this game on sale to anyone who enjoys simulation or strategy games, and deserves at least a look even at full price. I find it often an oddly relaxing game for me, but always engaging in the hunt for oil and even gas in the normal and expert campaigns that I've played at ~10 hours each.  Its a real time strategy game in that all actions are in real time when finding & drilling for oil. After each "year" in a location drilling, there will be an opportunity to buy upgrades, buy favors from people at the saloon, borrow cash from the bank, bid on the next place to drill, and later buy shares to become the mayor of the city. I would've considered bought this game in Early Access if I had known about it earlier, as it only spent one year there.

Pros:
+Presentation & music: Perfectly captures the essence of drilling for oil the 1800's with the game's looks and soundtrack, which helps the game be oddly relaxing for me. The latter comes free with the game, albeit with a short number of tracks.
+Strategy: There's the real time part of handling the finding and drilling of oil, along with fluctuating prices and whether to sell or store the oil for later selling at a higher price. Outside of the year to year operations, there's considerable strategy of what upgrades to buy and when versus land & town share bidding.
+Upgrades: There were plenty of upgrades such that I didn't get to unlock them all for any given town building. The game's expert mode made me focus on what's the most critical to getting all the oil drilled & sold in a given year.
+Integrated tutorials/tips: As you start out in the game, the tutorial is well done, and same goes for the tips given after buying most upgrades. Very few if any tips are isolated to the pay-to-open envelopes (nominal in-campaign cash) behind the mayor's office.
+Speed up & pause exist: I'm very glad there's a speed up option, which I found especially useful when I'm down to my last oil deposit and am just waiting for it to be emptied out. Pause is nice during realtime, but doesn't allow for you to do anything other than look at most of what's going on.
+Single Level customization: There's a mode that lets you setup a game year in a particular location along with the amount of oil, rocks, and/or gas. Can use seed numbers to share with other players and "compete" for higher scores.

Neutral:
~Ongoing periodic development: Dev game updates since release (#27-34) have averaged about once a month, which is good, but I'll just leave this quote from their Dec 14 2016 news/post here: "But we do like to investigate the possibility of more content in the form of a new map/areas. And if we do, we would probably want to add a game mechanic to the game. IF we go that direction we will consider releasing it as paid DLC. We‚Äôre also considering more drastic changes to the Single Level game mode that would allow for Leaderboards and Challenges." Give all existing owners the first DLC for free, and I'll move this to the Pros section ;)
~No mid year saving: On the pause menu there's an option to abort the current year, but that's the equivalent of stopping all your progress and only taking what $ you've already earned. My guess is that each year without pausing or speed up takes 10-15 minutes, so make sure you can dedicate that amount of time or be willing to pause after starting a new year.
~Only a little built in save scumming: The game saves immediately after a drilling year is over. So that means if you make some town purchases or bidding that you don't like, you can exit before going drilling (starting the next year), reload your save, and you'll be back in town as if that town stuff didn't happen. I only used this in town share bidding in expert mode a couple times, and I still lost the campaign.

Cons:
-Wagon management: Its simple and easy to use, which may be better than being too complex or cumbersome, but its simplicity can cause some inefficiencies that may lead to expensive oil spillage. Changing the wagons from one company to another (Left Inc vs. Right Inc) can be disruptive if any of them are carrying oil (fair for strategy I guess), you can't assign wagons to a particular rig, and can't assign a rig's oil to go to a particular company (if my rig is on the left side, I'd like some of its wagons/oil to go Left Inc). I wouldn't call the wagon logic terribly buggy though - Its just that on rare occasions some wagons will behave in a way I don't expect, most notably when wagon counts are split between left & right.
-Weak campaign end game: Winning the campaign only does two things - Gives at least one achievement and gives you a "Replay Bonus Island" where there's max oil, gas, and rocks. The island is cool but doesn't add much extra gameplay for me.
-Only 1 campaign save spot available: Didn't bother me, but might bother some people. Like mentioned earlier, there's very little save scumming built into this game.

EDIT: Added Pro about tutorial and tips.

This is a genuinely fun little game. Turmoil will not challenge you to the point of frustration, but it will offer just enough challenge to keep the game interesting.

You play as an oil prospector, drilling for oil. As another reviewer noted, however, the game is much more about transporting the oil, storing it, and selling it at the right times. If you run out of space to store the oil, or wagons to transport it, you don't just lose out on the oil: you spill it, and you get absolutely massive fines for doing so. Happily, with some forethought - or a bribe, after a few games in the career mode - you can avoid or reduce your fines for spillage.

Replayability is a concern, of course; it's a concern with any game this simple in concept. However, I find myself coming back to this game fairly regularly. If you happen to own Mini Metro, you may find that this fills the same niche - except, while Mini Metro plays until you fail (or eternally, depending on the mode you play), this game has a defined ending point, thus more effectively scratching the itch for a casual 30-or-so-minute game.

You can play in 'single mode', and test out strategies, but it feels kind of like playing a board game against yourself. The game is clearly designed around the career mode - and that's okay, because it's pretty great. Playing against the AIs is decent fun, and being able to upgrade your abilities after every game is nice. Picking your plot of land on the map at auction is surprisingly fun - I found it most effective to not try and find the most oil-rich area, and just make do with what I had, but your mileage may vary. After all, strategies working differently for different people is part of the fun of this game - there's no 'one' strategy that works, you find the one that works for you. And while the game lets you snowball when you're ahead, when you're behind, it gives you some ways back into it with cheap loans.

Overall, the game seems pretty well-thought out, and while it's not perfect, it's just FUN. It's a casual game, good for relaxing, but yet it's not Euro Truck - it's fairly thinky, even if the decisions you're making aren't overly complex. And while it's true that you can sometimes get more content in a $1 mobile game, at least this one doesn't mine your data and send it to China. At $10, Turmoil is quite reasonably priced - you probably won't play it every day, but you'll be glad to have it around when you want to chill out.

Use your profits to buy choice plots of land to drill, upgrade your technology and buy stock shares that will ultimately win you the game.  3 AI opponents, campaign-style world map, not too complex a game but enjoyable.

Neat little indie game. I'd probably classify it as a strategy-lite or resource management type game. There's a nice selection of upgrades and every "level" will keep you planning and thinking out the best strategy. The mechanics aren't super deep. There is a bit of cookie cutter builds that can lead to optimal results, and while some options are good and have trade-offs (should I bribe to fix oil prices and guarantee a steady early income, or should I roll the dice and rely on the fluctuations?), there are others that don't feel very compelling (why would I bribe for lower interest rates when taking out a loan is bad to begin with?).

The regular campaign mode took me 12 hours to beat, and there is an expert mode to unlock afterwords. Players versed in strategy games may find the regular mode pretty breezy, but it's still fun to challenge yourself and see if you can push that profit margin just a little bit further than last time.

OK - so I have played through most of the game and I have loved it, but I have lots of ideas on how it can be even better.
First off, should you buy this game? YES - absolutely. Easy to learn but plenty of depth too. You will be hooked on this game quickly, the power ups and money making are a very addictive strategy scenario.

OK, so here are the observations I have that could probably be improved to take the game from excellent to amazing:

* The game eventually becomes too repetitive after you beat the normal and expert mode.
* The expert mode didn't seem much different to me. It probably needs more changes to keep it interesting.
* The natural gas part of the game doesn't seem to quite come together at least for me. It's super expensive to get all the upgrades and lay the pipe need to use it. It's a neat idea, but it can be entirely skipped and you still win the game. To me, the game should be set up so that you need to take advantage of this in order to win. It seemed really hard to take advantage of this the way it was intended.
* The computer seems really dumb when it comes to the stock buying mechanic. I was able to buy up stock quite easily without being stopped by the CPU. By the fourth round I had had an insurmountable stock lead. The computer should be MUCH more aggressive when it comes to buying stock.
* The moles part of the game sounds interesting, but to me they just didn't seem to be worth the money or provide much benefit. You can basically just skip this and easily win. They dig up diamonds, but beyond that they didn't seem helpful.
*It would be great if you could do multiplayer local or over internet with a split screen. I would LOVE to play the game that way against a friend.

This is wonderful game for $6-$10 and I fully recommend it. It becomes repetitive and not quite so interesting after about 10 hours of gameplay, but this could be improved by the developers if they make some adjustments. It is just a bit too easy to win the game, and I wish the game would have been balanced to make we work harder to win.

Great Game!  For it's simplicity it's very entertaining.  Campaign took about 6 hours from start to finish.  Played my first game for a couple of hours getting used to how everything worked and learning the tools and such, then decided to start over because I was so far behind my Rivals.  Started the Second Game, now knowing what to do, beat my Rivals and was Elected Mayor in about 6 hours.

For $9.99, a game with a campaign that lasts at least 6 hours is a pretty good deal and well worth the price.

I really hope the devs add onto this game, with additional Campaigns/Modes to make this game even greater than it already is.  Because as of now, the only replay factor after completing the original Campaign is to try and get the Steam Achievements, if you are into that sort of thing.  

As for the Single Mode, to me it's not enough to keep you playing the game.  

[b]Gameplay - 4 out of 5 //[/b]  The Mechanics of the game worked well, the only issue that I experienced while playing was the cursor on my screen seemed off from where my mouse cursor was.  This only happened occasionally and really isn't that big of a deal, it didn't break the game or make it unplayable at all.

[b]Entertainment - 4 out of 5 //[/b]  The game is very entertaining and if you are someone like me, it is very easy to get sucked in and want to keep playing it until you beat the Campaign.  Don't be surprised if after starting the game, 6 - 10 hours have went by before you realize it.  At some point things will start feeling as if you are repeating the same thing over and over, but the Devs did do a Good Job at trying to mix things up, with the Auctions for the Land, the Upgrades to your Machinery, the Change of Environment of the land your drilling in (Some may be more rocky than others, contain more oil/natural gas than other and may or may not contain a Diamond).

[b]Replayablity - 2 out 5 //[/b]  To me, other than trying to get all the Steam Achievements, there is no replayablity for this game at the moment.  

Overall, the game is definately worth paying $9.99 for and is enjoyable.  If they were to add onto the game, with more gamemodes / Additional Campaigns I would be willing to pay more for the game.

I remember when games like this were free on Newgrounds. The gameplay is far too simplistic to be enjoyable. The only real opponent is the entirely arbitrary calendar that moves far too quickly to give the level any lasting impression. I suppose I was expecting more of a tycoon type game of starting out with one small plot of land, few resources, and basic tech, then expanding from there as you progress through the game. Instead, the first four levels played so similarly that I felt I was just replaying the saame thing over and over. Each round lasts about five minutes, the first ten seconds of which is spent waiting for the damn dowser to find any oil. That burns a week or two on the six-month calendar, even after buying a speed upgrade.

The cart AI is just terrible and completely uncontrollable. You'll think to yourself "OK, I'll build two rigs and some storage tanks, then when the price gets high I'll unload and make a killing!" Except you can't tell the carts to pull from the tanks first. Or which rig to pull from. YOU CAN'T COMMAND THEM AT ALL. The only solution to this is to buy enough carts to out-do the production of your rigs so they have no choice but to fill up from one of the storage tanks.

Oh, and you can't redo a level if you mess up. If you leave a level then that's it, you just lose money and move on.

I probably would have been ok with paying a dollar for this game, but even the discount of 40% isn't enough. I'd be FURIOUS if I had paid ten dollars for this, it absolutely failed to entertain at all. I gave it half an hour to see if maybe it just had a slow opening. Management game with the main purpose of becoming Mayor by making as much cash for the least outlay.

You do actually have to think a little with this game, judge whether it's worth searching for another oil pocket in the time remaining, or are you content you've got all the oil that's available and would the search be a waste of money.

I've not worked out a winning strategy yet, I keep going with the scanner upgrade, which I'm not sure is good, or if I'm just lazy.

Great little game, I very much enjoyed playing.

You are an oil tycoon starting with a limited budget hoping to strike it rich by choosing the right patch of soil to find the most oil, catchy huh?, and spending as little money as possible to extract it all out of the ground. All while trying to sell it for the best price. 

A series of available upgrades make this task easier when used right or more costly when used poorly. The AI competes against you in bidding for certain plots of land before you get to start building. Sometimes the plots can go for $1,000s in these bidding wars. 

There are two refineries to which you can sell your oil and the prices constantly fluctuate. But you only get a year to extract the oil from these plots. So, while you [b]can[/b] wait for a better oil price to come along, you can't wait forever. 

I would recommend this as a light, casual, management game as each level only lasts a short while, and you can even finish early.  

**I paid full UK retail price for this game via steam, and am in no way, shape or form affiliated with this game, its makers or publishers etc.**

I haven't played much of the game as of now, but I am pretty sure I've seen already quite alot of it.
For 10 Euros... well... that's actually quite disappointing. But before I get ahead of myself, let's start from the very beginning.

In Turmoil you basically just have to find Oil, sell it, make money and spend the money on... well things which will improve your way of making money, I guess.
That's pretty much it.
When I first heard of the game, it sounded like something I like. I just love idle games, clickers games, managment games or games where you actually... don't need to do much (because I am very lazy).
Even tho what I heard about the game got me excited, the excitement quickly started to drop after each minute of playing Turmoil. Why? Because even tho these types of games may be minimalistic, they most of the time still offer at least a few hours of content, even if it's just grinding and unlocking new stuff, but this game? Well...
It's kinda... well how should I put this?...
Boring to be honest.
For 10 Euros I at least expect some variation, even if it's just a little.
But in this game you pretty much do the same thing over and over again, with literally no ... challenge? Is that a good word to describe what I mean? I dunno.
It could have been good to some extend if there would have been more content, and with content I don't mean something like an extended story or exciting characters... or anything like that (because to be honest, these type of things don't really work all too well with these type of games) no, what I mean with content are things like Challenges, maybe different modes, or at least a leaderboard for god's sake...

Don't get me wrong, I do not hate this game, I just hate the fact that the game is being sold for 10 Euros, while other games are being sold for way less, and manage to offer WAY more content. I am a hobby programmer and I know how much work and time goes into a game, but to be fair, that doesn't mean that your game's value is automatically higher just because you put alot of effort into it.

I have to give the game some credit tho, because these days it is rather a rare thing to see a finished and "polished" game. Normally games are being crapped out even tho they are unfinished, buggy or anything like that.
So yeah, good job to whoever made this game, and I mean it! With a little more content, I even would have recommended this game, but at it's current state, there is literally nothing I could do or so without needing to lie.

If you want to support the creator, then go for it and buy the game. I - for my part - will not refund it, because I always support indie developers, as long as they are not throwing out a bunch of unfinished garbage.
But to everyone else, I sadly have to say that you might not want to spend your 10 bucks on this game.
If you're looking for some hours of casual fun, then you're wrong here. However, if you're looking for a few minutes a day of fun, then I guess the game could be suited for you. Just wait until it's on sale and grab it, because 10 bucks is way to much for the current game.

Turmoil was released on June 2nd of 2016. The game was developed and published by Dutch indie developer Gamious. Turmoil is a simulation game biased on 19th century oil rush. The game originally released on windows only but has since been ported to OSX and Linux. 
The main goal of the game is to become mayor beating out the other 3 oil tycoons of the city. This is done by competing in auctions for parts of the city but you need money for the auctions and this is where the oil comes in.

The main gameplay in turmoil is spent drilling for oil. Each round in turmoil consists of a calendar year where you have to make as much profit on the land. Prior to each round you have to bid on the land that you‚Äôll be using for the year and in later levels you also have to do a stock auction where a percent of the city goes up for sale. 

Once you‚Äôre out in the fields and drilling there‚Äôs really 3 main elements to the game. You have to find oil, drill for that oil, and transport it and sell it. Each element and timing is super important to having a good season. Each round usually starts out with you looking for oil usually by using dowsers who will indicate if there‚Äôs an oil patch beneath them. Usually there fairly accurate but sometimes I‚Äôll have one find oil and I just can‚Äôt figure out where it is. 

Now that you found oil it‚Äôs time to setup an oil rig and drill down. Your unable to see what‚Äôs in the ground until you drill so you have to guess where you think the oil patch is, usually its directly beneath a dowser. As you play though the game your able to upgrade your ability to look for oil beneath the soil with moles and eventually a scanner.
 
After your pumping oil you have to ether store it or sell it. If the oil rigs capacity goes over a certain amount the oil will spill and you‚Äôll get a fine at the end of the year. In order to transport the oil, you have to have horses and wagons move it ether to your storage facility or to the right or left company. As the year progresses the value of oil from each company is constantly changing so your goal is to sell the oil when the prices are high and store it when the prices are low in order to maximize your profits. 

At the end of each year your taken back to the town where your able upgrade pretty much every element of the oil drilling process. You can increase the maximum number of horses you can and how much they can carry or you can upgrade the pipes your oil rigs use In order to pump oil faster.

Additionally, in town your able to head to the bar and make deals with various people that will affect how the next year‚Äôs oil drilling will go. For instance, you can bribe the companies that buy your oil to keep their oil value above a certain level for the year, or you can bribe a city official to have your oil spillage fines waved for the year. 

As you progress in the game your taken though 4 areas that each have their own additions to the game‚Äôs gameplay. For instance, in the second area the desert you‚Äôll be introduced to rocks under the ground that can‚Äôt be drilled though unless you get a certain upgrade. These areas keep the game fresh and also raise the difficulty as you play. 

Turmoil is a blast to play, the way the game evolves as you upgrade your gear each year makes the game really satisfying and makes you feel like you‚Äôre making real progress from year to year. Looking for hidden oil pockets couldn‚Äôt be more fun. The game‚Äôs campaign can be beaten in about 2 hours, however the game has a lot of replay value and you can easy lose track of time playing it when your really getting into it.

Graphically turmoil‚Äôs minimalist and clean look makes the game look incredible especially on large screens. The games simple graphics make all the colors just pop making the game a delight to look at.
Turmoil‚Äôs sound might be the weakest part of this game with most of the soundtrack consisting of a steel string guitar playing old west sounding music but that‚Äôs not to say it‚Äôs bad. The music does fit the game and is nice and calm when works well with this type of game it‚Äôs just very forgettable and not something I‚Äôd seek out to listen to.

Overall Turmoil is an extremely solid simulation game that has easy to pick up and play game play that keeps me coming back. The Campaign as you play it really makes you feel like your progressing year by year thanks to the games upgrade system. The gameplay it‚Äôs self is a blast with enough things to balance and strategy to the game keeps it extremely engaging and fun to play. Turmoil is without a doubt worth checking out if your into simulation games.

This game is very easy to learn, casual, and a lot of fun.

[h1]Turmoil[/h1]:

In my opinion, one of the most calm but exciting games I have ever played.  The strategy and timing plays a key role in this game, as you have to manage money, sell oil to different companies, and time it all perfectly within a year.  On top of the mining, you can purchase upgrades to your oil rigs, horses, and so much more to keep you entertained with the 5-8 hour campaign.  After this, you can play single levels or go into the expert mode.

Cons:

-Normal campaign is a little on the easy side

-Replayability value is lacking

-Price is steep



Pros:

-Extremely addicting the first time around

-Expert and normal campaign to keep you busy

-Great soundtrack

-Overall just a very fun and unique experience!


Rating-_-_-_-  9/10
Great game. Good for its price.

Decent time-waster game, I feel like 10 dollars is just a bit pricey for this kind of glorified flash game. I think 5 dollars would be the right point, but if you have 10 laying around or there's a sale it could be worth it. Not too much replayability, but there's a solidly entertaining 5 hours playing the campaign through once. 

Familiar-feeling resource collecting/upgrading/selling game that is somewhat fun and feels very satisfying even though it isn't particularly innovative or standout. Main problem is that it just doesn't have too much depth, the upgrades are mostly the usual (collect resource X faster, store more of resource X, transport X faster) and none save one or two really change your strategy. 

The campaign lasts about 6 hours but becomes repetitive towards the end without enough new mechanics to shake it up. 

Overall: For $3 or $5 it could be a good time waster for a couple of hours, at 10 that is a bit too much for me.

[b]Turmoil[/b] is a simple thing, a time-passer with a pleasant sense of achievement rather than a grand, strategic opus. It‚Äôs the kind of game one can fit into the cracks around other things ‚Äì endless combative hours in The Witcher 3, for instance ‚Äì and I really do welcome that. As pleasant as it is though, I do wish that, given its subject matter, it had more character than whimsical guitar music and crisp, colourful art. But at least I don‚Äôt have to sit through endless irritating milkshake puns, eh? I can just be guilty of that myself instead.

This game is fun, but it kind of grows old quickly. It's good for maybe 6 hours, a little more depending on what you prefer, but it's not really a game made to be worth your money. I didn't remain entertained from this for too long, but others may be more entertained longer.

Turmoil is a building game.  The really interesting part of a building game is when you're setting yourself up for your success later on; which is one reason why Turmoil's limited-duration levels are such a clever design element.  It's not just a game of setting things up nicely, it's a game of setting things up quickly, of timing the market, and of sucking all the oil out of the ground in time for the 'early completion' bonus. (Unless you can make more money, or save more money, by using all the available time.)

I've just finished the beginner campaign, after a mostly-easy but occasionally stressful run that went closer to the wire than I expected.  Expert mode you say? Looks like this game will be eating more than one day of my life.  Very happy with the purchase.

Turmoil is an RTS resource and money management game set in the oil rush days of what one can only assume is the American West that is a lot of fun to play.

While having simplistic graphics don't let this game fool you, there is a decent amount of strategy here as the game progresses. This is one of the better mining/money managment games for it's price that I have played in a while.

While it is only $9.99 it will offer anyone playing between 6 to 12 hours of game play on the standard mode which then leads to an expert mode after completing the first run through.

Oil location is randomised which give the game a certain level of replayability but not as much as higher budget games

Pros

- Great aethstetic, graphics and music really suit the mood of the game
- Easy to learn game play that introduces new elements as the game continues forcing you to evolve your play style and come up with new strategies
- A fun and well priced game
- various upgrades to improve your gaming experience

Cons
-------------------
- Some may consider the game to be too short at a dozen hours long.
- The style of the game may not appeal to everyone.

[h1] NOTICE [/h1] : If you dont want to read the long review, i have provided a short one at the bottom. 

[b] Long Review [/b]

How can i put this game? Hmm. Its a Resource Management Simulator or in short, an Oil Tycoon! You basically have to get the most of the shares you can by the end of the game. To win you need to get 50% of the shares. Or more. Turmoil offers players a visually charming, tongue-in-cheek take on the simulation genre inspired by the 19th century oil rush in North America. You have to build a rig, create an efficient pipe network and bring up the oil to store it in silos. Sell the oil at the best times to maximize profits. Then buy essential upgrades in town to cope with rock, gas and ice. Acquire more town shares than your competitors in a bid to become the new mayor.

This game offers a campaign and a single game with all the items unlocked like Scanners, Moles and Drilling through rocks. The Campaign is a challenge and if you find it too easy and win the game, it offers you a new gamemode! The new mode is Expert. If you do not want the aim of Expert mode and the different characters to be announced, please do not hover over the black box.

[spoiler] In expert mode, there is 4 characters. Jim Bob, Larry, Lisa and Henry. This is different to normal mode due to them having advantages. All are different and its best to choose the one that suits you the most. Jim Bob's little cousin will run ahead and mark your first oil field before you even get there. That will be helpful so you may not need a dowser for a while and make more profit. Larry likes to live large and takes $2500 to each plot instead of $2000. This is very helpful and gives you an advantage than the other rivals. Lisa charms her way into Barney‚Äôs life and never has to pay Spillage fines. This is helpful if you are a Spillage..r? Henry is a Mole‚Äôs best friend. They will spot a Diamond for him without effort. This can be convinent if you want some more money than the other rivals. [/spoiler]

The game is fun and challenging and people say 'You finish it in 4 - 6 hours and thats it.' That is a lie. May take 4 - 6 hours depending on your speed to finish the normal campaign due to the easy AI Sytem. You hardly need to think and its just timing. Expert mode takes ages. You need to try it out! It is fun and will provide hours of fun.

This is a fun game and if you are commited to the repetetive gameplay, buy it and dont look back!
