This game is fantastic! Its a seemingly simple game, but has a large amount of depth. Finding the oil and extracting it is just the beginning. Once natural gas appears, the risk vs reward kicks into overdrive. Do I store all my oil and wait until I can sell at $2.00 from natural gas price boosts or do I start selling at $1.50 and sell more ALL of my oil. Later on you can even expand gas pockets.

The upgrade buildings add a tremendous amount of customization to gameplay. Moles, Dowsers, Horses, Pipes and Silos to name a few. You have to be careful how much you spend when stocks are introduced.

Honestly, just buy it already.

This is not exactly 'There Will Be Blood,' but you will learn to hate those other 3 characters with a fiery passion that will make their inevitable downfall to your oil empire all the sweeter. 

Careful management of money, upgrades and bribes is vital to this game, as well as field management of resources and taking advantage of price shifts between blu and red, you know, before they got into the gravel business. 

Once you complete the basic game and unlock the hard mode, you can really start pulling your hair out in rage over the other players. Anticipate spending about twice as long trying to beat those jerks than you did the first three. 

A fun game, a nice timewaster, and a good deal on sale.

Of all of the "Tycoon" / management type games I've played over the past few years, this one is the best. It's quite addictive and much more entertaining than the typical sims where you are in a storefront or similar. Highly recommend!

I bought this game with my own $10.00 US.

This game is not very deep but wow is it engaging.

Such a simple mechanic presented with simple visuals.

The idea is to lease a plot of land... spend a year looking for oil, drill it up, store or sell it (when price is high) without spilling it, hopefully while making an obscene profit, go back to town and purchase upgrades and technology, then do it all over again the next year while a western themed guitar gently plucks away in the background.

I seriously doubt I will spend hundreds of hours on it but I have already gotten my $10 of enjoyment out of it.

It is a great game that can be played between other larger titles.

Plus I got to support an indie developer that I would like to see make more games.

Highly recommended.

(old) I feel like I would love this game, simple, competitive (to an extent) and all round fun. The locked 30fps is unacceptable. The excuse they give for this.

 "Performance. It may look like a simple game, there are a lot of individual elements in the ground and above the ground, and the distribution of oil within the network needs quite some cpu as well.
Long story short: we tested the game on 60 fps on slower computers and it wasn't good enough. We don't want to leave them out." 

So you dont want to leave the people with slower PC's out and you do this by locking the frame rate to 30. Punishing the people with decent to high-end. Logic. They feel it is to much work to cap it at 60 or just let the few people with dinosaurs for PC's run at 50-20fps. 

If you are like me and 30fps makes you sick your stomach. Then do NOT get this game!

[h1]Will it Run?[/h1]

I have  a very low quality PC believe me when I say it, if I can run it so can you!

[h1]Graphics[/h1]

Graphics are beautiful, very sharp and clean and can be adjusted for your convenience.

[h1]Settings and Accessibility[/h1]

All music, sound, and effects can be adjusted along with a master volume slider.
*also the settings is extremely easy to find. The UI (User Interface) is very simple and easy to use

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

Some people who take a quick glance at this game before they buy it may look at it as a simple clicker game, (ex. adventure capitalist or cookie clicker..) but thats not the case, 

This game is fun to progress through and its very calm, I find that if I make a mistake in this game its not to much work to start over the game completely. This is because the only reason you would have to start over is because you may be new to the game and there is a small amount of trial and error aspects to purchasing upgrades for your tools in this game.

[h1]About The Game[/h1]

This game is about 4 characters (you being one of them) competeing in the oil market trying to strike heaps of oil patches for a quick profit. 
Theres only so much land you can mine up and destroy so when it comes down to it you have to start bidding for bigger peices of the land.
if you do however succeed in your oil mining oporation you can choose to expand with a vast amount of upgrades;
you can go from something as small as buying yourself a pet mole to help you find oil to upgrading to larger oil refineries to completely suck away any natural resources left in the earth. You may also find other treasures that lay beneath...

I rate this game an 8.5/10

It's not.

It is a nice game and fun for a while. Go out, find some oil, put down a drilling rig, lay some pipes, buy some wagons, sell the oil. If the price gets to low, put down a silo and store it for a while and sell it when the price is high again...
And Repeat.
And Repeat.
And Repeat.
But it becomes repetitive very quickly. Although there are upgrades you can buy, that help you do those things quicker and easier, it is basically the same thing over and over again.
The new elements like rock or gas pockets in later areas don't make it much less repetitive.
The price reasonable. If it‚Äôs on sale, you might still get it for some (short) fun.

It's pretty fun for what it is. A timekiller at best, really. The game itself is fun, but it just feels a little lacking. I think the main thing I found lacking is the upgrades, there are quite a lot of them, but only about ~20% are actually worth anything. There are a lot of really superficial upgrades that are mostly worthless or overpriced, not to mention a lot of the upgrades should really be passive, but instead require further spending during a mining year. I can understand the drill requiring a rig upgrade to be able to go through rocks, but purchasing the speed upgrade for your rigs is ridiculous, that should be a passive upgrade. Then most of the workshop upgrades are useless, really the only ones worth getting are the dowser upgrades.
Then there's the AI. On normal, they're pretty stupid, and will rarely make earnings anywhere near yours if you play well. But then, on expert, it's completely rigged against you. The first few digs you only get a month or half a year to mine oil, which barely allows you to get a few thousand dollars in earnings. However, your opponents will be making 10-20k in earnings, completely eclipsing you in the early game on expert, which only screws you over later on. The AI in general just needs a complete overhaul for balance.
That all said, it's still a fun game, I got it full price but frankly I would have to recommend waiting for the price to drop or it to go on sale to really be worth buying in its current condition. More content and some AI balancing would be really nice, along with reworking how some upgrades work.

Pretty disappointed with the lack of depth and complexity of this game. When I spent $9.99 on what is essentially a glorified flash game, I really expected something such as "Single game", which was proported to be "procedurally generated", to have quite a bit more to it, such as...you know, an endless world, which is what I think when I read "procedurally generated". Instead, it's just world seeds to make a single, constricted level that ends (completely) after 10 minutes of play. If it were, say, a giant world that never ends and there's endless possibilities and things to discover, that would make more sense when it comes to procedural generation. 

The campaign itself is just a string of single games and an added town where you can buy the upgrades, instead of just having them all like in Single Game. The campaign started to bore me after about 12 land leases. Everything is pretty linear, pretty simple, and really has no replay value once you've discovered everything there is to do, and realize how little time you have to actually play the game.

To put it bluntly and to the point, this game belongs on a free site like Kongregate, not on a platform such as Steam.

Ever wanted to bash someones head in with a bowling pin and drink their milkshake?

That's not exactly the game to do it, but it will bring you in the mood for it. ...I suppose every old-day oil magnat had these days.

In your first playthrough (took me about 10h) it's a light hearted simulation. The competition is not that dangerous, and will snatch precious land plots from you, but extend their financial ressources in the process. You will mitigate that and beat them in the long run. 

The levels itself play the same and you will develop a routine. Frequent upgrades to your equipment and the environment will ask some adapting of this routine. Mainly you gamble on waiting to sell your oil, hoping that the price will rise before the time is up or your silos full. Managing to get all oil and gas out and quitting early was the biggest achievment for me. 
Despite that there is little variation from the first level to the last, I was never bored with the game.

There is an 'expert' mode you unlock after finishing the first campaign, which should be more of a challenge. I might update this review, once I've played it.

CONS:

Many smaller, simpler games often fail because they have difficulty managing to stay challenging with a relatively simple premise--but this isn't one of those. This is one of those games that have the great combination of 'easy to learn, hard to master' going and manages to keep on your toes. 

The idea is simple, drill for oil and sell it. But with that simple premise you still have a lot of things that keep you always challenged:

Do you sell low and not worry about overflow or storage? If you choose to stockpile, you might run out of time and not get to sell the oil at all. 

You never know where the oil is, so how much will you invest in exploring for oil? If you don't, you might lose thousands of dollars in oil, but you might also waste thousands of dollars fruitlessly searching for oil that isn't there. 

How much money will you save for making important game winning purchases later in the game? (Won't get into that too much because, spoilers). If you save it all, you're going to miss out on important upgrades, but you could lose out on important things later on if you don't have any left. 

Best $10 game I've played in a LONG time. Buy it, at the very least it's a great 5-10 hours of fun.

The game takes place in 1899, during the 19th-century oil rush in the United States. Using hundreds of unique methods, you will search the ground for oil and build a thriving business. Selling to two major oil companies, you can decide the prices to sell your oil or store them in a tank until the price fluctuates to a more considerable value. Keeping track the different methods of earning money will keep your character from dropping out of the race.

Balance: 6
The balance is in the player's favor. Unfortunately, the artificial intelligence feels too easy to defeat.

Graphics: 8
These type of games are not created for utilizing high-end computer hardware, so they did great on finding choosing a distinctive style of art for the game.

Audio: 7
The music is excellent, and there are multiple sound effects throughout the game.

Content: 9
Luckily the game has a lot of packed in unique options to try new ways to win (or lose) the game.

Controls: 9
Incredibly easy to learn the game.

Gameplay: 7
It gave me several hours of entertainment, which was worth its price.


Overall: 7.6

Games go like this: 
- auction against AI competitors for land
- start digging game, its a few minutes long
- make money from your digging based on the amount of resource in your land and how succesfully you extract it
- go back in town to buy upgrades and get a new land
- mid game you start auctionning victory points against AI competitors

Note that you don't interact with AIs while in the digging part of the game, they don't affect oil market price or anything like that. Can't tell of expert mode as I haven't tried.

I feel it could use both a MP mode and a world map with varying lands for SP but that doesn't take away the fun it has to offer.

Got it on sale but felt polished enough to be worthy of the pricetag even for just 9h of play time.

I recommend this if you're looking for a fun casual management/strategy game.

I've never written a review for a game before. I can't honestly remember why I bought it or how I came across it. What I can say is its incredibly well made, bug free and above all else fun. It's an interesting mechanic and you improve along with the challenges so you feel like you are accomplishing something without being OP. You make choices that affect your gameplay and style. I have to say for the seemingly hundreds of games I've played this was quite a treat. Kudos to the developer, I am very happy with my time spent in your world. I hope you release some DLC or expand the game further, but if you don't I'll be looking out for your next game.

Getting right to it, Turmoil is a time-constrained pipe building optimisation puzzle game. Your main goal, and main problems will resolve around getting all the oil in a level out of the ground and sold within one year. It does what it does and it does it fairly well. The pipe building is intuitive(Simply drag the mouse to where you want it), and everything makes sense. Oil only flows as fast as the smallest pipe, thus you need to make sure you don't have a bottleneck in your system. And if you pump oil up faster than you can carry it away then you spill it, incurring a fine. The game explains mechanics well and there are enough upgrades and level varieties where it does not become a chore or too similar to other levels.

A solid foundation, improved upon by hazards such as rocks and natural gas which can be used for profit as well, with the right upgrades, or just by adding it to your regular oil pipes so the pressure brings the oil up faster. As before, you may spill some if you bring oil up too fast, so be careful about what you drill.
To further the gameplay there is a solid campaign that last just long enough to be a good experience without overstaying its welcome. You need to buy the upgrades, lease land you think has a good amount of oil in it, and compete with 3 AI players trying the same. Eventually leading to auctions for shares which allow you to win the campaign once you have a majority share. Even if you are not into optimising things, the base gameplay is well enough and the game forgiving enough that you can get away with a profit just drilling for oil, though you may have difficulty making large profit margins.

Turmoil is a simple but solid game, build on a good concept with good execution at a competitive price. If you're looking for a few days worth of entertainment, Turmoil is a good choice.

Does what it says on the tin. Turmoil's game mechanics are original and provide a satisfying exploration and puzzle solving experience. This is a casual game that will appeal to a broad audience of players.

Turmoil definitely goes down as an "easy to play, hard to master" game in which the premise is simple - become mayor of the town by buying up all the shares from the retiring mayor; having made your money by finding, extracting and selling oil.

Your base of operations is the town - where buildings offering upgrades become steadily available over the first few levels, and to get into the game proper - first you must buy land.  The tutorial is very quick, but guides you through without leaving you wondering what you're supposed to do.  There are four regions; divided into maybe 40 plots (I didn't count) meaning 10 levels to play, as each rival works on a different plot each round.  The amount of oil in each is random, but based on connecting plots - so once you've uncovered a few, you aim to choose the ones near areas where there was a good supply in the previous level, for the best chance of a playing area rich with black gold. Obviously your rivals will bid against you for what they think are the best plots, meaning sometimes taking a chance on an unexplored area or digging your heels in to try and burn through their money are both valid strategies.

When the game starts proper; things look incredibly simple.  Each level starts with a small amount of money from your main pot, from which you must buy dowsers (who prospect for oil underneath them) and wells (from which you can start drilling) and wagons - so you can transport the oil you bring up to the surface to one of the buyers, or to a silo if the prices aren't high enough. Oil supplies are limited but so is time to extract - with bonuses on offer for quitting the level early having extracted and sold all of the available product. Sell your oil to buy more of the tools, but save some money for profit to take into the next level - whatever you do, don't spill any because the fines are heavy.

For a game that's basically dragging and dropping pipes - there's a lot on screen to look at and do, and it's incredibly addictive.  Two days after buying, and I finished the campaign as the winner - only to find out I'm now invited to play expert mode against smarter competitors with special powers. 

All in all, a great distraction and one you'll definitely be able to play over and again thanks to its randomly generated levels and it's expert mode - but to nitpick; there should be a way to enter your own character name, high score tables for the levels and for the campaign as a whole so that you can check how well you're doing against previous plays.

The price of this game is WELL worth its weight in OIL. Yes, Turmoil had me hooked! What a fun game. I really enjoyed playing through regular mode. Now on to expert! This game is terribly additcting and MUCH fun. GET IT!

[b][i]Turmoil[/i] is a lot of fun![/b] While there is nothing super ambitious about this title, what it sets out to do - it does quite well. The game mechanic creates an interesting strategy/puzzle aspect that can be quite addicting.

[i]Essentially you are trying to turn profits by drilling for oil.[/i] Your success is largely dependent on things such as what strategy you choose to employ to find oil and extract it out of the ground. You have options to upgrade your equipment and abilities through spending your hard-earned money. This is definately a time-based game where you will drill for oil for a set amount of time, which obviously puts more emphasis on strategy.

What I really liked about [i]Turmoil[/i] is that it is pretty laid-back. I sat on the couch and only played with the mouse. My wife even got interested, which is rare. Nothing is too complex here - in fact this would probably do well on mobile. I hate mobile games (as many of you know), but this has just enough complexity to transcend that genre.

[b]Pros:[/b]
+Music is fitting, and quite nice.
+Game mechanic is simple to learn, yet takes a bit of time to master.
+Quite addicting.
+Price-point is definately spot-on for this title. I have no problems with the pricing.

[b]Cons:[/b]
-This would be [i]perfect[/i] for local hot-seat versus mode. Shouldn't be terribly difficult to implement (I'm not talking online mode, mind you).
-From looking at other reviews, mileage seems to top out somewhere between 10 and 20 hours (closer to 10). I'm fine with this, and think its appropriate, but just know this isn't going to be infinitely replayable IMHO.
-Mouse cursor needs to be darker or have more contrast (or at least have the option). This should be an easy fix.

[b]Yeah, definately a fun title to spend the weekend with.[/b] I'd recommend this at full price if it looks like your thang.

Turmoil is one of those brilliant games that hooks you in on beautiful looks and a concept so simple that it can't amazes you when you're still playing hours later. 

The setting is great, the gameplay engaging and the pacing actually well thought out. Unlocks aren't thrown at you straight away, and there's a real sense of building an empire based on performance. 

To this end, the customary 'throwing all the financial information at the player after each level' is well done and actually understandable to someone without a degree in business - something that very few business management games seem to get right.

If you're sat on the fence about buying this game, or want to laugh at my awful attempts to voice a 19th century Southern belle, then check out the play-though below.

https://youtu.be/qRKAJyE6NKk

Pro:

Cons:
Replay value
Variety of tech

Overall its a fun game, but it needs more difficulty options, more maps or regions than the basic 4, and new challenges to overcome during the game play. I would recommend the game, especially since it in it dev stage. There is alot of room and potential for growth and additional contecnt to extend and add game replay value.

--EARLY ACCESS REVIEW--
beta 0.248

There is a soft, almost zen like, wonderful quality to this game.  That isn't to say that this is an overly easy game or one lacking in challenge.  Far from it, figuring out what to spend money on, upgrades versus stocks, loans versus skipping a desired plot, there's a lot of depth and challenge to this game.  There were more than a few times when I left a round having lost money, and cursing choices I'd made.  But through it all, there's this sense of calm peacefulness as you play that puts you in a relaxed spot.

The music is a perfect fit for the setting.  Western themed, yet, again a bit soft and relaxing, save maybe the last month of each round where it takes on a slightly more frentic tone, reminding you to move that oil, even if it is at a loss.

The graphics are somewhat cartoonish and a bit simplified, but it works, and works well.

There are a few things I'd like to see, like maybe game settings, more or less opponents, a difficulty slider, etc.  Also some of the upgrades get ridiculously expensive.  FAR too expensive for how late in the game they appear, when you're trying to save money for stock auctions.

But over all, I'm amazed how much I enjoyed this game.  I ran through my first entire playthrough in a little over twelve hours, but I don't doubt I'll be giving it at least one more go-through before un-installing it.  I would recommend this game to anyone on the fence about buying it.

Updated Review:

After putting some serious work into this little time sponge I have a few more thoughts for potential buyers.

The people who are knocking it for being repetitive are not wrong, it is somewhat.   There is a fine line between risking repetitive and throwing too much at a player, I hope it gets a bit deeper, both in gameplay features as well as the ground itself in the late game in the future.

But those reviews saying "its not worth a dollar" have a REALLY messed up sense of value.   Go play Atari 2600, find the best games it had and prepare for disapointment and realize those were 25 bucks in 1980....like $80 todays money.
Turmoil was the price of a Starbucks Latte during the Christmas sale, even at full price you are going to hit under the dollar an hour price/fun mark easy.

The AI competition is weak right now, this might come as a relief for people that often get thrashed in some tycoon games (I do)  but pretty much if you can fog a mirror you are going to win the campaign mode.   So if you are looking for challenge NOW its not there, fair warning.   The AI is supposed to get better eventually‚Ñ¢ and there will be a hard mode someday.   The AI being potato heads doesn't affect the meat of the gameplay at all, but you WILL win.

Still totally a buy, fun to play now and you get to watch something addicting come together and be polished.   Its already way past the stage of being a potential money waste even if they just gave up tomorrow and did no more development.

Very fun game although the gameplay is slightly repetative. You dig for oil which you can sell or store while you wait for a higher price. Although you do the same in each scenario you can buy upgrades between levels which allows you to further improve your strategy.
At the same time you try to earn enough money to buy the town you are working in and to pay off random people in the saloon to get an edge in the next scenario.
The campaign, in it's current state, gives about 10 hours of fun, not that much but the game is still in Alpha. The current content isn't enough for a full game, but with some more content it can be great.

This game is a good example of what early access is supposed to look like. Every feature in the game works the way it's supposed to, I haven't encountered a single bug/glitch of any kind and I've been playing around with it for a couple hours now.

Pros:
-Easy game to understand and play, rules of gameplay are explained fairly quickly and without long sections of text to read.
-Fun light hearted humor
-No Bugs (or they're very well hidden)
-Quick game with autosave so it's easy to jump in and out of so you don't need to set aside an evening just to play it
-Stays within it's scope, most early access games have a huge list of features they want to implement but don't focus on the features that are already in play. These Davs have made a fully functional game and not left features dangling around in some half assed attempt to expand the game.

Cons:
-Gameplay is repetitive, I personally like the gameplay but unless you're playing the campaign setting there isn't a whole lot of nuance to the individual matches
-Some elements aren't fully explained, in the campaign you can bid for new land to expand your industry and the computer seems to have some algorithm in place which will cause them to pay up to 20x the base value of a property but there is no indication that it will be good. That is an example but there are a few similar incidents where the ai seems to know something or is capable of more while having less.

Overall I like this game and look forward to it's full release.

I can't explain it, but I'm super-addicted to this game.  The mystery of where the oil pockets are, how big they are and how to most efficiently and profitably get it out of the ground is fascinating.  The music is absolutely perfect too!  Some of the upgrades seem too pricey to be useful (the diamond upgrade for moles, and moles in general, the gas valves, Etc.).  The AI seems a little lacking - I have no problem far out-earning them.  I think multiplayer would be fun - real-time or, better yet, one turn at a time kind of a play-by-email style where Steam notifies you of your turn, you play one map, and then wait to be notified your friends have played and it's time for another turn.  Not sure if I like the gas mechanics or not.  When connected to oil, it pushes the oil out at ridiculous speed and there is always a spill.  I haven't spent the 40k to use gas to increase oil prices - not even sure how that would work or how much benefit it would really be.  Consequently, I haven't really played with the mechanic to expand the gas pockets because I don't use the gas much.  Also haven't found diamonds to be worth the trouble - they should be worth more money.

Not sure what to suggest for improvements - maybe mining?  Coal? Gold?  Maybe a way to collect and sell the gas?  Maybe some sort of underground gremlins that break pipes occasionally?  If mining, a cave-in perhaps?

I definitely recommend this game - you'll always want to play just one more map...

I bought this game on the launch sale, and so far I'm really enjoying it.

Essentially the game is broken down into two sections between which you alternate: In between years you are in the town doing upgrades and bidding on land to drill in the next year, and then you set off to your leased land to drill for the year.

Initially I was a bit thrown by the fact that you only get a limited time to drill for oil on every piece of land, but this is actually what makes the game brilliant. You can only lease each piece of land for a year, which means that you have to generate as much profit as possible during that time. Starting out you can't be sure exactly how much oil there will be on a given piece of land, which is interesting because:

1) If you invest too much early on (in carriages, oil drills, storage tanks) there might not be enough oil to justify the investment.
2) But if you don't invest enough you might not get a substantial amount of oil out and thus make less profit.

Add to this the fact that the two companies that you sell the oil to has prices that vary over time and you have a very interesting game about balance, efficiency and time management. Each time you start on a new piece of land, you gradually learn how much oil there is available, and you have to adjust your strategy accordingly to ensure maximum profit.

I'm glad I bought this game, looking forward to see how it develops!

[h1]Introduction [/h1]

Turmoil is a tycoon management game in which you dig for oil! It's 1899 in the land of the oil obsessed and it's time for you to get your share of the moolah coming out of this thriving industry. Start small, with four competitors and the most basic equipment and gradually work your way through the ranks, unlocking new equipment/upgrades as you go in order to out-grow the other businesses and eventually buy enough shares in the town to become its owner/new mayor.

I first played and reviewed this game in July of 2015, one month after its Early Access release. What I found was a good start to the game but there was only the first area of the campaign available and roughly two hours of game time to be had. In the months since then Turmoil has improved massively thanks to the hard work of the developers and the game now is as good as I would expect it to be at full release. My original review rated the game as ‚ÄòWorth Purchasing on Sale‚Äô.

[h1]Presentation [/h1]

It‚Äôs safe to say Turmoil is one hell of a good looking game. The art style is incredibly simple yet very easy on the eye and the models in the game all look great and remain consistent with the overall style. The UI is very good and while I do feel as though it‚Äôs a little bit too big when you‚Äôre actually in the drilling portion of the game it doesn‚Äôt block anything and so its size isn‚Äôt much of an issue.

[h1]Gameplay [/h1]

You begin each level by bidding on a plot of land, once you've acquired land you're given $2000 out of however much you have to start your oil venture. To find oil you send out dowsers (other methods are unlocked later) who will seek out oil for you, then you simply place a drill and put pipes down to wherever the oil is. You buy horse drawn carts to ferry your oil to one of two businesses or both though it's best to send all your oil to whichever gives you the best price per unit. Should you not be happy with the offered prices you can build oil storage units which hold a certain amount of oil, as soon as you decide to sell your oil again your horse drawn carts will take the oil from storage to whichever oil company you wish to sell to.

As I mentioned there are upgrades as well as new equipment to be unlocked as you progress. There‚Äôs at least one upgrade for every aspect of your drilling business from increased drill speed to faster dowsers. The upgrades start out relatively cheap but as you progress further in the game the new upgrades become more expensive. Some upgrades have multiple levels and the price for the next upgrade is always more than the one before it.

Returning to land in the game, there are four different regions for you to drill in, each one introducing a new gameplay element, I‚Äôll remain vague with what they are to avoid any possible spoilers. The first area is the most basic and is simply seeking oil and then selling it. The second, third and fourth areas all introduce at least one thing which can either benefit you or cause you some serious monetary losses depending on how careful you are in utilising it. Obviously that‚Äôs a bit of a generalisation for the purpose of staying vague but you get the idea. If you want to know exactly what is added in each area please ask and I‚Äôll put it in the comment section with a spoiler tag.

Returning to the bidding process, as with anything, it‚Äôs a bit of a gamble. Once an area has had its oil extracted by you or one of the AI players, it‚Äôs given a rating for how much oil it has generally between twenty and fifty where fifty is a load of oil and twenty is getting you nothing but chump change. These ratings are then visible to you next time you head to a land auction. While there‚Äôs no guarantee that the next area will have a good amount of oil the areas close to each other generally have a pretty similar rating and that‚Äôs how you have to decide where you wish to place a bid. This can also be a very strategic part of the game, if you play it right it‚Äôs relatively easy to get the AI to spend ridiculous amounts of money for a plot of land but that of course comes with the risk that they won‚Äôt outbid you and you‚Äôll be throwing your own money down the drain.

The stock auction, part of one of the game‚Äôs victory conditions, works in a very different way to the land auction. Each time you return to the town after twelve months of drilling for oil the mayor puts up a random number of shares for you to bid on. Bidding opens at the amount of money is held by the richest player and gradually decreases until either yourself or one of the AI characters decides to buy the shares for the price displayed.

[h1]Miscellaneous [/h1]
[list]
[*]Each area has its own environmental design and all four of them look great.
[*]The soundtrack fits well with the game‚Äôs style and is pretty relaxing but the game would benefit from having a couple more tracks thrown into the mix.
[*]Turmoil is kind of like those ‚Äòone more turn‚Äô games except you often start a new level without wanting to. I found myself so drawn into the game that I found myself starting a new level even when I had decided mere moments ago to turn the game off and play something else after finishing the level I was on. 
[*]There‚Äôs currently no way to save and quit during a twelve month drilling period which is quite annoying, if for some reason you need to go during a drilling period you have to stop the level, massively decreasing how much money you could have earned from that level. I asked the devs if they‚Äôd be adding this and they said it‚Äôs a possibility but it would be difficult for them to implement.
[*]The game needs a few things to be explained better, such as the fact that a triangle pipe connection means the pipe is drawing oil as well as the fact that pipes don‚Äôt need to lead to the bottom of an oil deposit to collect all of the oil. 
[/list]

[h1]Verdict [/h1]

[b]Worth Purchasing. [/b]

In its seven months of Steam Early Access, Turmoil has improved massively and become what feels like a full release title. Turmoil is a great management, tycoon game with a great art style, simple yet addicting gameplay and plenty of upgrades to keep things interesting throughout the campaign. If you‚Äôre a fan of management/tycoon games then this is definitely one worth picking up.

[h1]Early Access Review: TURMOIL[/h1]

[b]TL;DR: Ruining the environment has never been so satisfying[/b]

Rating:  4,1 of 5 - go for it!

[list]
    [*]artwork 8/10
    [*]addiction factor 8/10
    [*]early access progress 8/10
    [*]game mechanics 7/10 
    [*]replay value 10/10
[/list]

In Turmoil, you are supposed to make a fortune by drilling for oil in a western-like environment. Its visual appearence is fairly simple but charming.
 
Turmoil is one of those games, which are extremely [strike]addicting[/strike] satisfying - while the game mechanics are simple enough to avoid frustration, the gameplay leaves enough room for various strategies to succeed.

Whereas you are simply building oilrigs and horsecarts in the beginning, a good deal of technology becomes available as you progress in the game. Speaking of which, there are three different biomes: fertile land 1&2, desert and arctic. Within these areas, subplots are auctioned between player and AI.

This game is the perfect multitasking stimulus, maybe a little shallow in the end. Nevertheless, it is quite balanced - and loads of fun to play. As the oilpockets are randomized, the replay value is great,

[h1]PRO[/h1]
[list]
    [*]massive addiction factor
    [*]easy game meachanics
    [*]gameplay leaves room for different strategies
    [*]replay value 10/10
    [*]very good support by devs
[/list]

[h1]CONTRA[/h1]
[list]
    [*]feels a little shallow during late game
    [*]AI opponents could be tougher
[/list]

[h1]Early Access related problems[/h1]
[list]
    [*]no story in campaign mode/ real ending
    [*]occasional bugs (which get fixed regurlarly)
[/list]

41/50 - would support the developer team again!

I have played a few hours of this game and intend to play more. There is a few reasons why. First of all the game is being constantly updated to add new features and fix some very minor non gamebreaking bugs.  Secondly this games replayability is  insane. I feel as if I can play 100+ hours of this game and it only cost 10 dollars. Third of all the game features awsome music and it looks beautiful.  

I am in the process of a video series on this game and you can find it here: [url=https://youtu.be/7yT2B1Zn__0]here[/url].

A great premise, consistent artwork, and casual-yet-intense gameplay.

However, don't go in expecting a long-form strategy game. After you bid on a plot of land and go to develop it, you have exactly one day to extract from it before it's gone forever. No matter how much oil you pull out, once you've run out of time it's gone forever. That's a very different game than one where each plot continues to make money as you pull oil out of the ground, or one where you revisit the same plots over and over.

That's not necessarily a bad thing, the game is fun and challenging. But it's perhaps not the game I wanted to buy. This game is less of a meal and more of a snack, meant to be eaten in small portions before being abandoned. It's the sort of thing that feels like it looked wistfully at mobile games and wanted to fit in, but knew it was too complicated to do so.

The only real gripe I can bring up is that the prices of oil fluctuate _completely_ unexpectedly. There is obviously some pattern to when they rise and fall, and at what rate, but so much of the game is built on random chance that you'll be able to sell your oil to someone with a good price that it feels less as if you're getting better at the game, and more that you "struck oil" and got lucky with the RNG.

Again, that may just be how the game wants to be played. But to me the differences in my expectations and reality were enough to make me not want to play more.

This review will be semi long, grab a hot beverage and read it when you have 10 to 15 min, should break the game down for you well enough to figure out if you want to buy it or not.  TL:DR at the end for those of you that don't like :words:

Let me just say, that as a 35 yr old man I was COMPLETELY wrong about Turmoil.  I saw the graphics and I passed over Turmoil almost half a dozen times despite being 'recommend for you' over 4 times by steam.  The game is unfinished, but it's done enough that you'll have a really fun time playing it.  Most of the fixes or features that have to be finished are AI behavior, long term progression and most likely trying to make the game have a feature where you can simply continue after beating the 4 regions around the town.  

I'll have to admit, even though turmoil is only $10 I did my standard 'Lets watch a lets play to figure out if its REALLY worth it.'  I youtubed it and three 20 minute episodes later I had to buy it because it was driving me nuts just how inefficent the person playing the game was being.   

The game seems stupidly simplistic when you look at it and the first few levels will be childs play to all but the youngest gamers (sub 10 yrs old I would say) but the town development, oil drilling upgrades and trying to cost the AI players more funds just for the sheer hell of it make the game just become a truly awesome experience for me.

Anyone can dump down some prospectors, find the oil and sell it to one of the purchasing companies, and if that was all Turmoil was it would still be a [b]good [/b] game.  What makes it a [b]GREAT[/b] game comes from price flucuations, being able to hold product, upgrading your infrastruture per map (rig placement, silo placement, number of carts etc) and finally your underground pipeline placement on the later maps to gather natural gas and oil in a way that really makes you able to pump up your profits (pun intended).

And this game seems to have hit all the right buttons when it comes to being an economic game that many people would want to play.

1.  Simple to learn
2.  Complex to master
3.  Makes you want to play 'just one more map.'  (this had me playing it the first night from 11pm when I bought it to 4am on a work night, another good sign)
4.  The graphics, at first, seem childish but as the game progressed and the music played really grew on me enough that I was really enjoying the atmosphere after just 3 'turns'.
5.  The sound track is actually really well done, for a $10 game I find that refreshing and a tad inspiring that the game dev's put this sorta effort into it.
6.  You can tell this isn't just a 'lets make cash' game that many indie games seem to be these last years.  You can TELL it's been a labor of love for the developers.

If this is any indication of what the devs/game studio is capable of I'm going to write some suggestions for them and I'm going to hope like CRAZY that we'll see a Turmoil 2 within a year or two.  

I've played tons and tons of economic games over the past 30 years, from something as simple as Lemonade stand (back on a 386 , to as complex as EVE online and everything in between.  If I had the means, I'd love to see these guys write something with this level of care and passion as I felt when I played the orginal "Industry giant 2" or "Capitalism".  Yes, it's reaching a big, BIG bit, but I've seen a massive derth in this genre compared to seeing an endless stream of FPS clones of CoD, RTS's that can't match up to Starcraft and all sorts of studios that produce endless clone after clone while chasing the same dollars that would be theirs with a little orginalility.   Turmoil is [b]ORGINAL[/b] and the devs haven't been stomped on by that 'corporate' mentality that screams 'shove the game out the door so we can meet payroll.'   I really, really, REALLY hope they don't lose that and their next games are just as good, if not better then this.

Turmoil has been an unexpected treat for this 'old' gaming vet and I'm recommending it to anyone at all that enjoys playing economic games.  I'd go so far as to say that if Turmoil was $20 I'd still buy it after seeing the let's play I saw on Youtube.  After actually playing it I can say it's underpriced and with the winter sale screaming our way, it'll be dirt cheap shortly for those that are budget consious.  It's a budget meal at the moment and you should consider it.  

Oh and they aren't done yet, I was reading their announcements and they aren't close to being done yet.  Oh and they are activily responding to suggestions, questions and bug reports on their steam forum page.  That's a very nice touch to me, they might not want to hear from this grizzild old vet but I have hope that they will. 

I always try to sum up my reviews/articles with a TL:DR, so here goes.

[b][u]TL:RD[/b][/u] Do I recommend Turmoil?  After almost 5 years of games being 2x to 4x as expensive Turmoil had me playing 'just one more turn' after the first 20 minutes for a 5th of the cost.   You bet your A$$ I recommend it.

This game is amazing already. It has a slight boardgame feel with the map view, with players bidding on plots of land they believe have the most oil, with a risk of bidding lots on a plot with little to tons of oil. Then to the actual game of finding the reserves of oil and pumping it up. Then, the stategic game of either selling [i]now[/i] or storing the oil till prices rise. The price of oil for both sellers fluctuate constantly, so knowing [i]when[/i] to sell is just as important as knowing how much to spend on carts, rigs, and silos. 

It almost seems at this point the AI cheats by knowing how to find oill, without having to spend money on upgrades, so they'll always have the most money. Being in Early Access though, I'm hoping that a multiplayer mode takes off, because this game versus 3 other actual people would be glorious.

My initial review of this game was a big fat "NO."  after playing through the entire campaign i felt that it wasn't worth my money, and that the only reason i bothered sticking with it was due to the completionist in me.  it was repetitive, dragged out, and got boring.

In the few short months since then, the developer has impressed me.  They've directly communicated with me to address some concerns, they've provided updates at an impressive rate, and they have directly addressed concerns, issues, and recommendations of the community.

This isn't one of the "take your money and run" alphas.  This is a constantly updated and supported ealry access game.

Due to the attention and activity of the developer, and the updates applied in a short period of time, this game now feels like it's worth the money i spent on it.  i now look forward to the additions and changes, and watching this game grow.

As for the game itself, it's a fun little number.  it's got pretty unique gameplay compared to other small games on Steam.  it's easy to pick up, and a fun time killer.  the music fits the theme and era of the game, and is pleasant now that there's more than one track.  The features and  upgrades that have been added give more of a reason to keep playing.

Drilling for oil is an interesting process, filled with high stakes risk-reward decisions in a competitive environment with never enough information when commiting your resources.  There's a lot of room for awesome gameplay in this space.  Turmoil... doesn't really deliver on it though.

[h1]Locating Oil:[/h1]
   [b]How it really works:  [/b]
    Geologists study local surface rock formations to decide where to survey, and then analyse those surveys to determine likely spots to drill  Skill at both steps determines the value
    [b]How Turmoil handles it:[/b]
    Pick a spot on the board at random, or near previous finds.  Hire a unit that tells you there's a deposit below a specific spot.  Infallibly, although the amount of oil is completely random.
    [b]What's missing[/b]
    Even M.U.L.E. had assaying.  Geographic information is a closely guarded corporate secret, with scanning technology and the ability to put various public and proprietary data together into a useful whole to determine a good drill spot provide game play, upgrade paths, and player differentiation.

[h1]Land Acquisition[/h1]
    [b]How it really works: [/b]
    High stakes negotiations with landholders to determine lease costs.  This includes clauses such as minimum production targets, as well as land use restrictions  (can't drill near the farmhouse)
    [b]Turmoil[/b]
    Buy land for a set rate, or 'outbid' another player by paying the current rate + X$  (remember, you're doing this largely blind.
    [b]What's missing[/b]
    Players are currently bidding on the next property based on identical costs and perfect information.  There's no risk/reward, no 'I know something you don't' about bidding, and no 'my tech means I can get oil out of this property better than you'  Even delaying the announcement of total oil on other players land by a turn (and/or limiting that information to what they actually got) would create a more interesting bidding space.  Is that low number a sign that the other player is bad, or that there wasn't anything to find?  Did they get lucky and find all the oil early and close to the surface, or is it a good spot to drill?


[h1]Drilling[/h1]
    [b]Reality:[/b]
    Complicated process involving drilling long distances while monitoring a variety of readouts to determine the status of a drillbit 1000s of feet under the surface, including where exactly underground you are and what you're drilling through.
    [b]Turmoil[/b]
    Click to drill your pipe to a specific location, including twists and turns
    [b]What's missing[/b]
    This one isn't so bad, although exploratory drilling could be more interesting/informative

[h1]Production[/h1]
    [b]Reality[/b]
    Lots of stuff comes out of the ground.  It needs to be managed, processed and routed correctly.  Wells are either pumped or naturally flowing based on positive pressure.  Should the well be produced (oil extracted) or shut in to build up pressure (for greater flow later).  Water or gas can be injected to increase pressure.  Pumped wells often burn oil or gas coming from the well to power themselves.  Lease requirements mean a certain amount of production must be maintained.
    [b]Turmoil[/b]
    Wells flow until empty, but make sure the oil is being hauled away or else it'll blow!
    [b]What's missing[/b]
    Risk/Reward for maximizing a well's production, the value of production now vs. over time.

[h1]Sales[/h1]
    [b]Reality[/b]
    This one may be anachronistic, but in addition to price differentials, different purchasers have different quantities they'll accept on a given day.
    [b]Turmoil[/b]
    Time management game determining which to sell to vs. cost of storage.
    [b]What's missing[/b]
    I really like the cost of storage vs. sales now, except so far as it is a timed map and you've got to sell everything at the end.  That seems just silly.  Making sure the wagons go to the higher price, though, is time management in the worst way.  Anachronistic, but the cost of a pipeline (faster, cheaper movement of oil) vs trucking (or wagons) is another good decision point.

[h1]Shut in[/h1]
    [b]Reality[/b]
    All wells continue to produce as long as it is viable to operate them.  This involves balancing ongoing costs with the perception of a wells future profitability.  Lease requirements play into this, and there is a significant cost involved in shutting a well down.
    [b]Turmoil[/b]
    You have a few months to a year to drill for oil in a spot.  Regardless of your rigs, your lease is up at the end of the year, and you lose anything that's left unsold.  Risk/reward is entirely based around 'will I have time to make this back if I spend it now'
    [b]What's missing[/b]
    This is the weakest part of the game (imho).  It turns the game into a rush rush rush time management sim rather than allowing the player to focus on serious risk/reward decisions, like if I drill here, how much oil will I get, and will that be enough to pay for the drilling.  Is it worth drilling another well to maintain the lease, even if the well isn't likely to produce much?


Basically, this is a time management game.  The risk reward decisions are all there, but they are forced by artificial and silly time limits rather than likely profits.  In addition, several opportunities to allow players to develop unique strategies (find the best oil fields,  produce the oil efficiently, manage land efficiently, etc) are missed.

I'd like to see this game improve, but as long as it's leaning so heavily on time managment tropes, I'm going to stay away.

I enjoyed the game, up until the most recent update completely wiped my campaign progress, and made me start for level 1 again. I spent a good amount of time to get there, and now i'm expected to start again? Bring in the steam achievements, and maybe even some trading cards for me to play it again. Despite this, it still is a good game to play, and if I had to rate it with what happened, I would probably rate it as a 3 of 5. The first star would be earned through the fun gameplay and campaign that you play through. The second star would have to be for the graphics, the game looks great overall. And the 3rd star would be that the game is good for people who like to build/adapt to different enviroments with the same overall layout ( ex: oil/rocks are in different places/depths every map ). Now, that being said, I should probably say why this game loses 2 stars. The first reason would probably be, that as soon as you cap the upgrades, that's it, there's nothing better. This partially halts the gameplay, making it impossible to get any better. The second star that this game loses would probably be that it gets repetitive as you go on. With no upgrades to buy, you're doing the same thing over and over again time and time again. Overall, this is a fun game for anyone who enjoys a bit of strategy/resource management, and likes the gameplay offered.

More like a Flash game than something I'd buy on Steam, especially for this price.

In general the game seems interesting. Overall it feels more like an unpolished casual 
freemium game. Current 8.99 EUR price tag not reasonable, imho.

Criticism:

 * window controls are odd/inconsistent. (regarding close/ok button)
 * accesing town houses wind up the house owner animation. it is just annoying
 * it would be nice if I could preview the bidding landscape. at some point it will help to maintain you bankroll
 * if you get only a bad piece of land (mid / late game) you will most likely sit there 6 month and do nothing because all oil is drilled or inacessible at reasonable investment
 * upgrade costs seem imbalanced. you can probably only afford many of them if you're ahead each drill. on the other hand oil seems quite limited.

2/5

I have some advice for developers (Hope they read it):

- It'll be nice to have a kind of stock market or a trade place to make the player motivated to still earn money. Because if you bought all upgrades there is no use for it any more. (Or at least the option for a high score overview)

- The finance report is bad. To big and actually not that easy to understand... As well it'll be nice to see the report at main menue; like a high score botton!

- In the game under the left inc. and the right inc. the bottons feel a little to big for my taste. I know it's good to control via touch screen, but sometimes I can't select the pipe to build there.

- If I play with a resolution less than 1600 x ... the bottons over the oil pump, to uprade those, are in the interface. It's just a bit annoying...

- I don't like the map because it feels like I play a browser game... As well it's easy to make the ai to spend its money for the land parcels. And to scroll will be better with the right mouse botton.

- In town: More upgrades and maybe buildings to buy.

- In game screen: More depth, maybe water which can make the oil dilute and useless..., the diffrence between scanner upgrades is to low, the horse upgrade to see how many wagons you have is not good - should be there from the beginning.

I recommend this game to anyone who likes economic-strategy-games. For its size it's quite looking good.
Nice work and thanks a lot.
Didn't even hold my attention for ten minutes. It's just to simple and repetetive. I wouldn't even play this on my phone in the bathroom.

Fun little time waster game that is pretty well polished for an early access game.   

There are a couple bugs, but they are pretty minor compared to some games that make it onto Early Access. I didn't run into anything game-breaking.   

Took me about 4 hours before I basically had all the upgrades and there wasn't much else to keep me going.  Some more variety in map types and the upgrades themselves would be welcome, but there is certainly a solid foundation for a decent game here.

Just one more round. Just one more level. One more upgrade. One more attempt.
Rather addictive, and reasonably bug free for an early access.
A small expansion on features, a bit more optional detail on screen (individual and total flow rates could be implemented as in game upgrades), and a bit more flavour between stages will see this game tighten up into a good little indie adventure.
A surprisingly pleasant game, that hits the spot just right. A bit rough around the edges but with great promise. : )
10/10 Won't refund <3

Decent effort here - a game with more potential than actualized game, Turmoil is an interesting way to spend an hour getting all the way to mid-game, then quickly becomes tedious. However there is a lot of room for expansion here, I would like to see more in the way of character-to-character interactions, as the only reason the other characters even matter is they bid on properties you might very well want. I'd like to see a deeper upgrade system, more end-game content, more smaller passive upgrades, I'm not too sure honestly, but the point is there's room to build on an interesting concept.

I seldom buy relativly simple made Indy-titles (this one has only about 30MB) for almost full price ("only" 10% discount at the moment). There are regulary enough AAA-titles for this amount of money or less, but I desperatly miss the 80s-title "Oil Empire", and so I gave it a chance. Of course it is not the same, but fr me, the feeling of this game here comes close (at least for me). So I would definely say: the money was well spent. 

Some suggestions for further game-improvement, would be: 

1) A better AI during the land auctions. Of course, properties with explored rich oilfields nearby should be more attractive. But the differences on chance are not explaining, why the AI is sometimes willing to spend much more money than the competioners for a piece of land right next to it (and loosing too much hard earned money by doing so). The AI seems to extract quite at a good rate, but then spends too much money in this situation and falling back in the ranking. 

2) I have so far no idea, what the AI is doing outside the auctions. There seems to be no information, how the AI-competitioners are earning their money. The amount they earn, could as well be randomly generated. Or how they spend it (except for buying their piece of land). So I discovered no information about their strategies with technology and everything else. Also their little background-story is not making clear, if there are any differences in the NPC-strategies at all. I would like to have some more information about them and ... 

3) I would like to interact with my NPC competitioners. How about robbery, espionage, sabotage, ... Of course combined with meaningful consequences for victims (like broken pipes or leaking tanks) and caught evil-doers (like shortened extraction time because of short inprisonment and so on). This could involve strategy-aspects in town and on the region map as well as little mini-games.

So finaly, I would say: Nice game, worth the money, whith a solid core-concept in a sadly unterrepresented genre, with fitting graphics and a nice simple background-music. But also with a lot of chances, to get even better. But there is already much more, than just the infamous early-access-"potential". 

Thanks developers! You did a very good job so far. Please keep going!
